editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Nayoon Ahn

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

Based on day 10, novel 10 of: Boccaccio, Giovanni. Decamerone.

div.p: The pleasant comedy of patient Grissel.
As it hath been sundry times lately played by the right honourable the Earl of Nottingham (Lord high admiral) his servants.
London. Imprinted for Henry rocket, and are to be sold at the long shop under s. Mildred's church in the poultry. 1603.

div.head: The pleasant comedy of patient Grissel.
div.stage: Enter the marquess, Pavia, Mario, Lepido, and huntsmen: all like hunters. A noise of horns within.

sp.speaker: Marquess.
sp.l: Look you so strange my hearts, to see our limbs
Thus suited in a hunter's livery?
O 'tis a lovely habit, when green youth
Like to the flowery blossom of the spring,
Conforms his outward habit to his mind,
Look how yond one-eyed wagoner of heaven,
Hath by his horses fiery winged hooves,
Burst open the melancholy jail of night,
And with his gilt beams cunning alchemy,
Turned all these clouds to gold, who (With the winds)
Upon their misty shoulders bring in day:
Then sally not this morning with foul looks,
But teach your jocund spirits to ply the chase,
For hunting is a sport for emperors.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.l: We know it is, and therefore do not throw
On these your pastimes, a contracted brow,
How swift youth's bias runs to catch delights,
To me is not unknown: no brother Gualther,
when you were wooed by us to choose a wife,
This day you vowed to wed: but now I see,
Your promises turn all to mockery.

sp.speaker: Lepi.
sp.l: This day yourself appointed to give answer
To all those neighbour-princes, who in love
Offer their daughters, sisters and allies,
In marriage to your hand: yet for all this
The hour being come that calls you to your choice
You stand prepared for sport and start aside:
To hunt poor deer when you should seek a bride.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Nay come Mario your opinion too,
He'd need of ten men's wit that goes to woe.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: First satisfy these princes, who expect
Your gracious answer to their embassies,
Then may you freely revel: now you fly
Both from your own vows, and their amity.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: How much your judgements err: who gets a wife
Must like a huntsman beat untrodden paths,
To gain the flying presence of his love.
Look how the yelping beagles spend their mouths
So lovers do their sighs: and as the dear,
Outstrips the active hound, and oft turns back
To note the angry visage of her foe,
Who greedy to possess so sweet a prey,
Never gives over till he cease on her,
So fares it with coy dames, who great with scorn
Show the care-pined hearts, that sue to them
Yet on that feigned slight, (Love conquering them)
They cast an eye of longing back again,
As who would say, be not dismayed with frowns,
For though our tongues speak no: our hearts sound
Or if not so, before they'll miss their lovers,
Their sweet breathes shall perfume the amorous air yea,
And brave them still to run in beauty's chase:
Then can you blame me to be hunter like,
When I must get a wife: but be content,
so you'll engage your faith by oath to us,
Your wills shall answer mine, my liking yours,
And that no wrinkle on your cheeks shall ride.
This day the marquess vows to choose a bride.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Even by my honour,

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Brother be advised,
The importunity of you and these,
Thrusts my free thoughts into the yoke of love,
To groan under the load of marriage,
Since then you throw this burden on my youth
Swear to me whosoever my fancy choose,
Of what descent, beauty or birth she be,
Her you shall like and love as you love me.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Now by my birth I swear, wed whom you please,
And I'll embrace her with a brother's arm.

sp.speaker: Lepi.
sp.l: Mario and myself to your fair choice,
Shall yield all duties and true reverence.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Your protestations please me jollily,
Let's ring a hunter's peal, and in the ears
Of our swift forest, citizens proclaim,
Defiance to their lightness: our sports done,
The venison that we kill shall feast our bride,
If she prove bad, I'll cast all blame on you,
But if sweet peace succeed this amorous strife,
I'll say my wit was best to choose a wife. Exeunt,

div.stage: As they go in, horns sound and hollowing within: that done, enter Janicolo, Grissil, and Babulo, with two baskets begun to be wrought.

sp.speaker: Bab.
sp.p:
Old master here's a morning able to make us work tooth and nail (Marry than we must have victuals) the sun hath played boe peep in the element any time these two hours, as I do some mornings when you call: what Babulo say you: here master say I and then this eye opens, yet done is the mouse, lies still:
what Babulo says Grissel, anon say I, and then this eye looks up, yet down I snug again: what Babulo say you again, and then I start up, and see the sun, and then sneeze, and then shake mine ears, and then rise, and then get my breakfast, and then fall to work, and then wash my hands, and by this time I am ready: here's your basket, and Grissel I here's yours.

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.p: Fetch thine own Babulo let's ply our business.

sp.speaker: Bab.
sp.p: God send me good luck master.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: Why Babulo, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Bab.
sp.p: God forgive me, I think I shall not eat a peck of salt: I shall not live long sure, I should be a rich man by right, for they never do good deeds, but when they see they must die, and I have now a monstrous stomach to work, because I think I shall not live long.

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.p: Go fool, cease this vain talk and fall to work.

sp.speaker: Bab.
sp.p: I'll hamper somebody if I die, because I am a basket maker. Exit.

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.p: Come Grissel, work sweet girl, here the warm sun will shine on us,
sp.l: And when his fires begin,
We'll cool our sweating brows in yonder shade.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: Father, methinks it doth not fit a maid,
By sitting thus in view, to draw men's eyes
To stare upon her: might it please your age,
I could be more content to work within.

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.l: Indeed my child, men's eyes do now adays,
Quickly take fire at the least spark of beauty,
And if those flames be quenched by chaste disdain,
Than their envenomed tongues (Alack) do strike,
To wound her fame whose beauty they did like.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: I will avoid their darts and work within.

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.l: Thou needst not, in a painted coat goes sin,
and loves those that love pride; none looks on thee,
Then keep me company: how much unlike
Are thy desires to many of thy sex?
How many wantons in Salivia,
Frown like the sullen night, when their fair faces
Are hid within doors: but got once abroad,
Like the proud sun they spread their staring beams,
They shine out to be seen, their loose eyes tell,
That in their bosom's wantonness do dwell:
Thou canst not do so Grissel, for thy sun,
Is but a star, thy star, a spark of fire,
Which hath no power t'inflame doting desire:
Thy silks are threadbare russets: all thy portion
Is but an honest name: that gone thou art dead,
Though dead thou liv'st, that being unblemished.

sp.speaker: Gris.
sp.l: If to die free from shame be never to die,
Then I'll be crowned with immortality.

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.l: Pray God thou mayst: yet child my jealous soul
Trembles through fears, so often as mine eyes
Sees our Duke court thee: and when to thine ears
He tunes sweet love-songs: o beware my Grissel
He can prepare his way with gifts of gold,
Upon his breath, winged promotion flies
O my dear girl trust not his sorceries,
Did he not seek the shipwreck of thy fame?
Why should he send his tailors to take measure
Of Grissel's body: but as one should say,
If thou wilt be the marquess concubine,
Thou shalt wear rich attires: but they that think,
With costly garments, sins black face to hide,
Wear naked bravery and ragged pride.

sp.speaker: Gris.
sp.l: Good father do not shake your age with fears
Although the marquess sometimes visit us,
Yet all his words and deeds are like his birth,
Steeped in true honour: but admit they were not,
Before my soul look black with speckled sin,
my hands shall make me pale death's underling,

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.l: The music of those words sweeten mine ears
Come girl let's faster work: time apace wears.

div.stage: Enter Babulo with his work.

sp.speaker: Gris.
sp.p: Come Babulo why hast thou stayed so long?

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: Nay why are you so short, masters here's money I took (Since I went) for a cradle: this year I think be leap year, for women do nothing but buy cradles, by my troth I think the world is at an end, for as soon as we be born we marry: as soon as we marry we get children, (By hook or by crook gotten they are) children must have cradles, and as soon as they are in them, they hop out of them, for I have seen little girls that yesterday had scarce a hand to make them ready, the next day had worn wedding rings on their fingers, so that if the world do not end, we shall not live one by another: basket making as all other trades runs to decay, and shortly we shall not be worth a button, for none in this cutting age sow true stitches, but tailors and shoemakers, and yet now and then they tread their shoes a wry too.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Let not thy tongue go so: sit down to work
And that our labour may not seem too long,
We'll cunningly beguile it with a song.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Do master for that's honest cousinage.

div.stage: The song.

lg.l: Song art thou poor yet hast thou golden slumbers:
O sweet content!
Art thou rich yet is thy mind perplexed?
O punishment.
Dost thou laugh to see how fools are vexed?
To add to golden numbers, golden numbers.
O sweet content, of sweet etc.
Foot work apace, apace, apace, apace ▪
Honest labour bears a lovely face,
Then heigh nonny, nonny: heigh nonny, nonny.
Canst drink the waters of the crisped spring,
Oh sweet content!
Swimmest thou in wealth, yet sinckest in thine own tears,
Oh punishment.
Then he that patiently wants, burden bears,
No burden bears, but is a King, a King,
Oh sweet content, etc.
Foot. Work apace, apace, etc.

div.stage: Enter Laureo.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: Weep master, yonder comes your son

sp.speaker: Ian.
sp.l: Laureo my son? o heaven let thy rich hand
Pour plenteous showers of blessing on his head.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Treble the number fall upon your age,
Sister?

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: Dear brother Laureo welcome home.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: Master Laureo) (Anicula's son) welcome home, how do the nine muses, pride, covetousness, envy, sloth, wrath, gluttony and lechery? you that are scholars read how they do.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Muses: these (Fool) are the seven deadly sins.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: Are they: mass methinks it's better serving them, than your nine muses, for they are stark beggars.

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.p: Often I have wished to see you here,

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: It grieves me that you see me here so soon.

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.l: Why Laureo dost thou grieve to see thy father,
Or dost thou scorn me for my poverty.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: He needs not, for he looks like poor John himself, eight to a neck of mutton, is not that your commons, and a cue of bread?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Father I grieve my young years to your age,
Should add more sorrow.

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.p: Why son what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: That which to think on makes me desperate.
I that have charged my friends, and from my father
Pulled more than he could spare, I that have lived,
These nine years at the university,
Must now for this world's devil: this angel of gold,
Have all those days and nights to beggary sold,
Through want of money, what I want I miss,
Who is more scorned than a poor: scholar is?

sp.speaker: Bab.
sp.p: Yes three things: age, wisdom, and basket makers

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: Brothers what means these words?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: O, I am mad.
To think how much a scholar undergoes,
And in th'end reaps naught but penury.
Father I am enforced to leave my book,
Because the study of my book doth leave me,
In the lean arms of lank necessity.
Having no shelter (Ah me) but to fly
Into the sanctuary of your aged arms.

sp.speaker: Bab.
sp.p: A trade, a trade, follow basket-making, leave books and turn block head.

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.l: Peace fool, welcome my son, though I am poor
My love shall not be so: go daughter Grissel,
Fetch water from the spring to seethe our fish,
Which yesterday I caught: the cheer is mean,
But be content, when I have sold these baskets,
The money shall be spent to bid thee welcome:
Grissel make haste, run and kindle fire. Exit Grissill.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: Go Grissel I'll make fire, and scour the kettle, it's a hard world when scholars ease fish upon flesh days

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Is't not a shame for me that am a man,Exit. Ba.
Nay more, a scholar to endure such need,
That I must pray on him, whom I should feed?

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.l: Nay grieve not son, better have felt worse woe
Come sit by me while I work to get bread,
And Grissel spin us yearn to clothe our backs.
Thou shalt read doctrine to us for the soul,
Then what shall we there want, nothing my son
For when we cease from work even in that while,
My song shall charm griefs ears and care beguile.

div.stage: Enter Grissill running with a pitcher.

sp.speaker: Gris
sp.l: Father as I was running to fetch water,
I saw the marquess with a gallant train
Come riding towards us, oh see where they come.

div.stage: Enter marquess, Pavia, Mario, Lepido, two ladies and some other attendants.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: See where my Grissel, and her father is,
Methinks for beauty shining through those weeds,
Seems like a bright star in the sullen night.
How lovely poverty dwells on her back,
Did but the proud world note her as I do,
She would cast off rich robes, forswear rich state,
To clothe them in such poor abiliments,
Father good fortune ever bless thine age.

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.p: All happiness attend my gracious lord.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.p: And what wish you fair maid?

sp.speaker: Gris.
sp.l: That your high thoughts.
To your contentment may be satisfied.

sp.speaker: Mar,
sp.l: Thou wouldst wish so, knewest thou for what I come
Brother of Pavia behold this virgin,
Mario Lepido is she not fair?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Brother I have not seen so mean a creature,
So full of beauty.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Were but Grissel's birth,
As worthy as her form, she might be held
A fit companion for the greatest state.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: O blindness, so that men may beauty find,
They ne'er respect the beauties of the mind,

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Father Ianicola what's he that speaks

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.p: A poor despised scholar and my son.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: This is no time to hold dispute with scholars
Tell me in faith old man what dost thou think,
Because the marquess visits thee so oft?

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.l: The will of prince's subjects must not search,
Let it suffice, your grace is welcome hither.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: And I'll requite that welcome if I live,
Grissel suppose a man should love you dear,
As I know some that do, would you agree
To quittance true affection with the like.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: None is so fond to fancy poverty.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I say there is: come lords stand by my side,
Nay brother you are sped and have a wife,
Then give us leave that are all bachelors,
Now Grissel, eye us well and give your verdict,
Which of us three you hold the properest man,

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: I have no skill to judge proportions.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Nay then you jest, women have eagles eyes,
To pry even to the heart, and why not you?
Come, we stand fairly, freely speak your mind,
For by my birth, he whom thy choice shall bless,
Shall be thy husband.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What intends your graft?

sp.speaker: Lepi.
sp.p: My lord I have vowed to lead a single life,

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: A single life? this cunning cannot serve,
Do not I know you love her I have heard?
Your passions spent for her your sighs for her,
Mario to the wonder of her beauty,
Compiled a sonnet.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I my lord write sonnets?

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: You did entreat me to entreat her father,
That you might have his daughter to his wife.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: To any one I willingly resign,
All interest in her, which doth look like mine,

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: My lord I swear she ne'er shall be my bride,
I hope she'll swear so too being thus denied,

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Both of you turned apostates in love,
Nay then I'll play the crier: once, twice, thrice,
Speak or she's gone else: no since 'twill not be,
Since you are not for her, yet she's for me.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: What mean you brother?

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Faith no more but this:
By love's most wondrous metamorphosis,
To turn this maid into your brother's wife,
Nay sweet heart look not strange I do not jest,
But to thine ears mine amorous thoughts impart,
Gualter protests he loves thee with his heart,

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: The admiration of such happiness,
Makes me astonished.

sp.speaker: Gris.
sp.l: O my gracious lord,
Humble not your high state to my low birth,
Whom not worthy to be held your slave,
Much less your wife.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Grissel that shall suffice,
I count thee worthy: old Janicola,
Art thou content that I shall be thy son?

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.l: I am unworthy of so great a good.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Tush tush talk not of worth, in honest terms
Tell me if I shall have her? for by heaven
Unless your free consent allow my choice,
To win ten kingdoms I'll not call her mine.
What's thy sons name?

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.l: Laureo my gracious lord.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: I'll have both your consents: I tell ye lords,
I have wooed the virgin long, o many an hour,
Have I been glad to steal from all your eyes,
To come disguised to her: I swear to you,
Beauty first made me love, and virtue woe,
I loved her lowliness, but when I tried
What virtues were intempled in her breast,
My chaste heart swore that she should be my bride
say father, must I be forsworn or no?

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.p: What to my lord seems best to me seems so

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.p: Laureo what's your opinion?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Thus my lord.
If equal thoughts durst both your states confer,
Here's is too low, and you too high for her,

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.p: What says fair Grissel now?

sp.speaker: Gris.
sp.l: This doth she say,
As her old father yields to your dread will,
So she her father's pleasure must fulfil.
If old Janicola make Grissel yours,
Grissel must not deny, yet had she rather,
Be the poor daughter still of her poor father.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: I'll gild that poverty and make it shine,
With beams of dignity: this base attire,
These ladies shall tear of, and deck thy beauty
In robes of honour, that the world may say,
Virtue and beauty was my bride today.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: This mean choice, will distain your nobleness

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: No more Mario than it doth disgrace
The sun to shine on me.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.p: She's poor and base.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.p: She's rich: for virtue beautifies her face.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.l: What will theworld say when the trump of fame
Shall sound your high birth with a beggar's name?

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: The world still looks a squint, and I deride
His purblind judgement; Grissel is my bride,
Janicola, and Laureo: father, brother,
You and your son graced with our royal favour,
Shall live to outwear time in happiness.

div.stage: Enter Babulo.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: Master I have made a good fire: sirrah Grissel, the fish

sp.speaker: Ian.
sp.p: Fall on thy knees thou fool: see here's our Duke

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p:
I have not offended him, therefore I'll not duck
and he were ten Dukes.

lg.l: I'll kneel to none but God and my prince.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: This is thy prince, be silent Babulo,

sp.speaker: Bab.
sp.p: Silence is a virtue, marry 'tis a dumb virtue: I love virtue that speaks, and has a long tongue like a bell-wether, to lead other virtues after: if he be a prince, I hope he is not prince over my tongue, snails, wherefore come all these: master here's not fish enough for us, sirrah Grissel the fire burns out.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.p: Tell me my love what pleasant fellow is this?

sp.speaker: Gris.
sp.p: My aged father's servant my gracious lord.

sp.speaker: Bab.
sp.p: How, my love: master a word to thewise, scillicet me my love.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.p: What's his name,

sp.speaker: Bab.
sp.p: Babulo sir is my name ▪

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.p: Why dost thou tremble so? we are all thy friends

sp.speaker: Bab.
sp.p: Its hard sir for this motley jerkin, to find friendship with this fine doublet.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.p: Janicola bring him to court with thee.

sp.speaker: Bab.
sp.p: You may be ashamed to lay such knavish burden upon old ages shoulders: but I see they are stooping a little, all cry down with him: he shall not bring me sir, I'll carry myself.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.p: I pray thee do, I'll have thee live at court,

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: I have a better trade sir, basket-making,

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Grissel I like thy man's simplicity,
Still shall he be thy servant Babulo,
Grissel thy mistress, now shall be my wife

sp.speaker: Bab
sp.p: I think sir I am a fitter husband for her.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.p: Why shouldst thou think, I will make her rich

sp.speaker: Bab.
sp.p:
That's all one sir, beggars are fit for beggars, gentlefolks for gentlefolks: I am afraid that this wonder of therich loving thepoor, will last but mine days: old m bid this merry gentleman home to dinner, you shall have a good dish of fish sir: and thank him for his good will to your daughter gris. for I'll be hanged if he do not (As many rich cogging merchants) now adays do when they have got what they would,
give her the bells, let her fly.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: O bear my lord with his intemperate tongue

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.p: Grissel I take delight to bear him talk.

sp.speaker: Bab.
sp.p: Ay, ay, you're best take me up for your foul: are not you he, that came speaking so? to Grissel here, do you remember how I knocked you once for offering to have a lick at her lips.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: I do remember it and for thy pains,
A golden recompense I'll give to thee.

sp.speaker: Bab.
sp.p: Why do, and I'll knock you as often as you list.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Grissel this merry fellow shall be mine,
But we forget ourselves, the day grows old.
Come lords cheer up your looks and with fair smiles,
Grace our intended nuptials: time may come,
When all commanding love your hearts subdue,
The marquess may perform as much for you. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Farneze, Urcenze, and rice meeting them running.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.p: Rice how now man? whether art thou galloping?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: Faith even to find a full manger: my tooth water till I be munching, I have been at the cutlers, to bid him bring away sir Owen's rapier, and I am ambling home thus fast, for fear I am driven to fast.

sp.speaker: Vrc.
sp.p: But sirrah rice, when's the day? will not thy master sir Owen and signior Emulo fight?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: No, for signior Emulo has warned my master to the court of conscience, and there's an order set down, that the coward shall pay my master good words weekly, till the debt of his choler be run out.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.p: Excellent, but did not Emulo write a challenge to sir Owen.

sp.speaker: Rice.
sp.p:
No he sent a terrible one, but he gave a sexton of a church a groat to write it, and he set his mark to
it, for the gull can neither write nor read.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: Ha ha, not write and read? why I have seen him pull out a bundle of sonnets written, and read them to ladies.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.p: He got them by heart Urcenze, and so deceived the poor souls: as a gallant whom I know, cozens others: for my brisk spangled baby will come into a stationer's shop, call for a stool and a cushion, and then asking for some Greek poet, to him he falls, and there he grumbles God knows what, but I'll be sworn he knows not so much as one character of the tongue.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: Why then it's Greek to him.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.p: Ha, ha, Emulo not write and read?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: Not a letter and you would hang him.

sp.speaker: Vrc.
sp.p: Then he'll never be saved by his book.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: No nor by his good works, for he'll do none. Signiors both, I commend you to the skies, I commit you to God, adieu.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.p: Nay sweet rice a little more,

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: A little more will make me a great deal less, house keeping you know is out of fashion: unless I ride post, I kiss the post: in a word I'll tell you all, challenge was sent, answered no fight, no kill, all friends, all fools, Emulo coward, sir Owen brave man, farewell, dinner, hungry: little cheer, great great stomach, meat meat, meat, mouth, mouth, mouth, adieu, adieu, adieu. Exit.

sp.speaker: Vrc.
sp.p: Ha, ha, adieu rice, sir Owen belike keeps a lean kitchen.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.p: What else man, that's one of the miserable vows he makes when he's dubbed: yet he doth but as many of his brother knights do, keep an ordinary table for him and his long coat follower.

sp.speaker: Vrc.
sp.p: That long coat makes the master a little King, for wheresoever his piece of a follower comes hopping after him, he's sure of a double guard.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.p: I'll set some of the pages upon thy skirts for this

sp.speaker: Vrc.
sp.p:
I shall feel them no more than so many fleas,
therefore I care not: but Farneze you'll prove a most accomplished coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.p: O old touch lad, this younker is right Trinidado pure leaf tobacco, for indeed he's nothing purffe, reek, and would be tried (Not by God and his country) but by fire, the very soul of his substance and needs would convert into smoke.

sp.speaker: Vrc.
sp.p: He's steel to the back you see, for he writes challenges.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.p: True, and iron to the head, o there's a rich leaden mineral amongst his brains, if his skull were well digged, sirrah Urcenze, this is one of those changeable silk gallants, who in a very scurvy pride, scorn all scholars, and read no books but a looking glass, and speak no language but sweet lady, and sweet signior and chew between their tooth terrible words, as though they would conjure, as compliment and projects, and fastidious, and capricious, and misprision, and the sintheresis, of the soul, and such like raise velvet terms.

sp.speaker: Vrc.
sp.p: What be the accoutrements now of these gallants?

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.p: Indeed that's one of their fustian outlandish phrases to, marry sir their accoutrements, are all theatheistic fashions, that can be taken up, either upon trust or at second hand.

sp.speaker: Vrc.
sp.p: What's their qualities?

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.p: None good, these are the best: to make good faces: to take tobacco well, to spit well, to laugh like a waiting gentlewoman, to lie well, to blush for nothing, to look big upon little fellows, to scoff with a grace, though they have a very filthy grace in scoffing, and for a need to ride pretty and well.

sp.speaker: Vrc.
sp.p: They cannot choose but ride well, because every good wit rides them.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.p: Here's the difference, that they ride upon horses, and when they are ridden they are spurred for asses, so they can cry wehee and hollow kicking jade, they care not if they have no more learning than a jade.

div.stage: Enter Emuloes sir Owen talking, rice after them eating secretly.

sp.speaker: Vrc.
sp.p: No more of these jadith tricks: here comes the hobby horse.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.p: O he would dance a morris rarely if he were hung with bells.

sp.speaker: Vrc.
sp.p: He would jangle villainously.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.p: Peace let's encounter them.

sp.speaker: S. o.
sp.p: By cod sir Emuloes, sir Owen is clad out a cry because is friends with her, for sir Owen swear, did her not swear rice?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: Yes forsooth. Spit out his meat.

sp.speaker: S. Ow.
sp.p: By cod is sweare terrible to knog her pade, and fling her spingle legs at plum trees, when her come to fall to her tagger and fencing trigs, yes faith and to breag her shins did her not rice?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: Yes by my troth sir.

sp.speaker: S. Ow.
sp.p: By Cod's udge me is all true, and to give her a great teale of bloody nose, because sir Emuloes you challenge the Prittish knight, rice you know sir Owen gentleman first, and secondly knight, what apoxale you rice, is shaken now?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: No sir I have my five senses and am as well as any man.

sp.speaker: S. o.
sp.p: Well here is hand, now is mighty friends.

sp.speaker: Emu.
sp.p: Sir Owen

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.p: Now the gallimaufry of language comes in.

sp.speaker: Emu.
sp.p: I protest to you, the magnitude of my condolement, hath been elevated the higher to see you and myself, two gentlemen.

sp.speaker: S. Ow.
sp.p: Nay 'tis well known sir Owen is good gentleman, is not rice?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: He that shall deny it sir I'll make him eat his words.

sp.speaker: Emu.
sp.p: Good friend I am not in the negative, be not so capricious, you misprise me, my collocution tendeth to s. Owen's dignifiing.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Let's step in, God save you signior Emulo.

sp.speaker: Vrc.
sp.p: Well encountered s. Owen.

sp.speaker: S.o.
sp.p:
Owe, how do you s. Em. is friends out a cry now
but Emuloes take heed, you match no more love trigs to widow Gwenthyan's, by cod urge me, that do so must knoge her, see you now?

sp.speaker: Emu
sp.p: Not so tempestuous sweet knight: though to my disconsolation, I will oblivionise my love to the Welsh widow, and do here proclaim my delinquishment, but sweet signior be not too diogenical to me,

sp.speaker: Sir o.
sp.p: Ha ha is knowe not what genicalls mean, but sir Owen will genicall her, and her fag her genicalling Gwenthyan.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.p: Nay faith we'll have you sound friends indeed, otherwise you know, signior Emulo, if you should bear all the wrongs, you would be our athlassed.

sp.speaker: Emu.
sp.p: Most true.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: By god is out a cry friends, but harg Farneze, Urcenze twag a great teale to Emuloes: owe. is great teale of friends: ha ha is tell fine admirable shest, by cod Emuloes, for fear s. Owen, knog her shines, is tell, sir Owen by dozen shentlemen her pooets is put about with lathes, ha, ha, serge her serge her.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: No more tell Urcenze of it: why should you two fall out for the love of a woman, considering what store we have of them? Sir Emulo I gratulate your peace, your company you know is precious to us, and we'll be merry, and ride abroad: before god now I talk of riding, sir Owen methinks has an excellent boot.

sp.speaker: Vrc.
sp.p: His leg graces the boot.

sp.speaker: S. Ow.
sp.p: By God is fine leg and fine poote to: but Emula's leg is better, and finer, and shenglier skin to wear.

sp.speaker: Emu.
sp.p: I bought them of a penurious cordwainer, and they are the most incongruent that ere I beware.

sp.speaker: S. Own.
sp.p: Congruent? 'sploud what leather is congruent, Spanish leather?

sp.speaker: Emu.
sp.p:
Ha ha, well gentlemen I have other projects beckon for me, I must digress from this bias, and leave you: accept I beseech you of this vulgar and domestic
compliment.

div.stage: Whilst they are saluting, sir Owen gets to Emulo's leg and pulls down his boot.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Pray Emuloes let her see her congruence leather ha ha, owe what a pox is here: ha, ha, is mag a wall to her shins, for keeb her warm?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: What's here lathes? where's the lime and hair Emulo,

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: O rare, is this to save his shins?

sp.speaker: S. Ow.
sp.p: Ha, ha, rice go call Gwenthyan,

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: I will master Dahoma, Gewnthyan Dahoma?

sp.speaker: S. Ow.
sp.p: A pogs on her go sedge her and call her within

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: I am gone sir. Exit rice.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Nay sir Owen what mean you?

sp.speaker: S. Ow.
sp.p: By cod is mean ta let Gwenthyan see what booby fool love her, a pogs on you.

sp.speaker: Emu.
sp.p: Sir Owen and signiors both, do not expatiate my obloquy, my love shall be so fast conglutinated to you.

sp.speaker: S. Ow.
sp.p: Cod's plud, you call her gluttons, Gwenthyan, so ho Gwenthyan?

sp.speaker: Emu.
sp.l: I'll not digest this pill, signiors adieu.
You are fastidious and I banish you. Exit Emulo.

div.stage: Enter Gwenthyan.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: God's so, here comes the widow, but in faith sir Owen say nothing of this.

sp.speaker: S Ow.
sp.p: No go to them, by cod sir Owen bear as prave mind as emperor.

sp.speaker: Gwe.
sp.p: Who calls Gwenthyan so great teale of time?

sp.speaker: Vrc.
sp.p: Sweet widow even your countryman here.

sp.speaker: S. Ow.
sp.p: Belly the ruddo whee: wrage witho, Mandageny mou du ac whellock en uvea awh.

sp.speaker: Gwe.
sp.p:
Sir Owen gramarrye whee: Gwenthyan Mandage
any, ac wellock en thawen en ryn mogh.

sp.speaker: Far
sp.p: Mundage Thlawen, o my good widow gabble that we may understand you, and have at you.

sp.speaker: S. Ow.
sp.p: Have at her: nay by cod is no have at her to, is tawge tn her Prittish tongue, for 'tis fine delicates tongue, I can tell her. Welsh tongue is finer as Greek tongue.

sp.speaker: Far
sp.p: A bakte neat's tongue is finer than both.

sp.speaker: S. Ow,
sp.p: But what says Gwenthyan's now? will have sir Owen, sir Owen is known for a wisely man, as any since Adam and Eve's time, and that is by gods udge me a great teale ago.

sp.speaker: Vrc.
sp.p: I think Salomon was wiser than sir Owen.

sp.speaker: S. Ow.
sp.p: Salomons had pretty wit: but what say you to King Tavie: King Tavie is well known was as good musicians, as the pest fiddler in aul Italy, and King Tavie was sir Owen's countryman, yes truly a Prettish shentlemen porne, and did twinkle, twinkle, twinkle, out a cry upon welsh-harp, and 'tis known Tavie love mistress Persabe, as sir Owen loves Gwenthyan: will her have sir Owen now?

sp.speaker: Far
sp.p: Faith widow take him, sir Owen is a tall man I can tell you.

sp.speaker: S. Ow.
sp.p: Tall man, as God unde me, her think the Prittish shentelman, is faliant as Mars that is the fine knaves, the poets say the god of pribles and prables, I hope widow you see little more in sir Owen then in sir Emuloes, say shall her? have her now, 'tis faliant, as can desire, I warrant her.

sp.speaker: Gw.
sp.p: Sir Owen, sir Owen, 'tis not for faliant, Gwenthyan care so much, but for honest and fertuous, and loving and pundall to lead her have her will.

sp.speaker: S. Owe.
sp.p: God udge me, tage her away ▪ to her husband, and is led her have her will owd a cry, yet by God is pridle her well enough.

sp.speaker: Gw.
sp.p:
Well s. Owen, Gwenthyan is going to her cozen
Gualther the Duke, for you know is her near cousin by marriage, by tother husband that pring her from Wales.

sp.speaker: Ow.
sp.p: By cod Wales is better country than Italy's, a great teale so better.

sp.speaker: Gw.
sp.p: Now if her cousin Gualther say Gwenthyan tage this Pritish knight, shall love her diggon: but must have her good will: marg your thad sir Owen.

sp.speaker: Ow.
sp.p: Owe what's else: sir Owen marg that ferrewel, yet shall tage her down quiglie enough, come widow will wag to the coward, now to her cozen, and bid her cozen tell her mind of str Owen.

sp.speaker: Gw.
sp.p: You'll man Gwenthyan sir Owen?

sp.speaker: Ow.
sp.p: Yes by cod and pravely to, come shentlemans you'll tag pains to go with her?

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.p: We'll follow you presently sir Owen.

sp.speaker: S. Ow.
sp.p: Come widow: un lod dis glane Gwenthyan mondu

sp.speaker: Gw.
sp.p: Gramercy wheeh, am a mock honnoh. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.p: So this will be rare: sirrah Urcenze, at the marriage night of these two, instead of Io Hymen, we shall here heigh ho Hymen, their love will be like a great fire made of bay leaves, that yields nothing but cracking noise, noise.

sp.speaker: Vrc.
sp.p: If she miss his crown 'tis no matter for cracking,

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.p: So she soader it again, it will pass currant.

div.stage: Enter Onophrio and Julia walking over the stage.

sp.speaker: Vrc.
sp.p: Peace here comes our fair mistress.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.p: Let's have a fling at her.

sp.speaker: Vrc.
sp.p: So you may, but the hardness is to hit her.

sp.speaker: Ono.
sp.p: Farewell Farneze you attend well upon your mistress,

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Nay, nay, their wages shall be of the same colour that their service is of.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.p: Faith mistress would you had travelled a litile sooner this way, you should have seen a rare comedy acted by Emulo.

sp.speaker: Vrc.
sp.p: Every courteous mouth will be a stage for that, rather tell her of the Welsh tragedy that's towards.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: What tragedy?

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.p: Sir Owen shall marry your cousin Gwenthyan,

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Is't possible: o they two will beget brave warriors: for if she scold he'll fight, and if he quarrel she'll take up the bucklers: she's fire and he's brimstone, must not there be hot doings than think you?

sp.speaker: On.
sp.p: They'll prove turtles, for their hearts being so like, they cannot choose but be loving.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Turtles: turkey-cocks, for god's love let's entreat the Duke my brother, to make a law, that wheresoever sir Owen and his lady dwell, the next neighbour may always be constable, lest the peace be broken, for they'll do nothing but cry arm, arm, arm.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.p: I think sir Owen would die rather than lose her love

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: So think not I.

sp.speaker: On.
sp.p: I should for Julia, if I were Julie's husband.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Therefore Julia shall not be Onophrio's wife, for I'll have none die for me.

lg.l: I like not that colour.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.p: Yes for your love you would Julia.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: No nor yet for my hate Farneze.

sp.speaker: Vrc.
sp.p: Would you not have men love you sweet mistress?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: No not I, fie upon it sweet servant.

sp.speaker: On.
sp.p: Would you wish men to hate you?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Yes rather then love me, of all saints I love not to serve mistress Venus.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.p: Then I perceive you mean to lead apes in hell.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: That spiteful proverb was proclaimed against them that are married upon earth, for to be married is to live in a kind of hell.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.p: I as they do at barleybreak.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p:
Your wife is your ape, and that heavy burden wedlock, your Jack an ape's clog, therefore I'll not be tied to't: master Farneze, sweet virginity is that
invisible godhead that turns into angels, that makes us saints on earth and stars in heaven: here virgins seem goodly, but there glorious: in heaven is no wooing yet all there are lovely: in heaven are no weddings yet all there are lovers.

sp.speaker: On.
sp.p: Let us sweet madam turn earth into heaven, by being all lovers here to.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: So we do to an earthly heaven we turn it.

sp.speaker: On.
sp.p: Nay but dear Julia, tell us why so much you hate, to enter into the lists of this same combat matrimony?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: You may well call that a combat, for indeed marriage is nothing else, but a battle of love, a friendly fighting, a kind of favourable terrible war: but you err Onophrio in thinking I hate it I deal by marriage as some Indians do the sun, adore it, and reverence it, but dare not stare on it, for fear I be stark blind: you three are bachelors, and being sick of this maidenhead, count all things bitter, which the physic of a single life ministers unto you: you imagine if you could make the arms of fair ladies the spheres of your hearts, good hearts, than you were in heaven: o but bachelors take heed, you are no sooner in that heaven, but you straight slip into hell.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.p: As long as I have a beautiful lady to torment me, I care not.

sp.speaker: Vrc.
sp.p: Nor I the sweetness of her looks shall make me relish any punishment.

sp.speaker: On.
sp.p: Except the punishment of the horn Urcenze, put that in.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Nay he were best put that by: lord, lord, see what unthrifts this love makes us? if he once but get into our mouths, he labours to turn our tongues to clappers, and to ring all in, at Cupid's church when we were better to bite off our tongues, so we may thrust him out, Cupid is sworn enemy to time, and he that loseth time I can tell you loseth a friend.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: I a bald friend.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p: Therefore my good servants if, you wear my livery, cast of this loose upper coat of love: be ashamed to wait upon a boy, a wag, a blind boy, a wanton: my brother the Duke wants our companies, 'tis idleness and love, makes you captains to this solitariness, follow me and love not, and I'll teach you how to find liberty.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: We obey to follow you, but not to love you, no renounce that obedience.Exeunt

div.stage: Enter the marquess and Furio.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Furio.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Thy faith I oft have tried, thy faith I credits
For I have found it solid as the rock:
No babbling echo sits upon thy lips,
For silence even in speech, doth seal them up,
Wilt thou be trusty Furio to thy lord?

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: It is enough, those words I will,
Yields sweeter music than the gilded sounds,
Which chatting parrots long tongued sycophants,
Send from the organs of their Siren voice,
Grissel my wife thou seest bear in her womb,
The joy of marriage: Furio I protest,
My love to her is as the heat to fire,
Her love to me as beauty to the sun,
(Inseparable adjuncts) in one word,
So dear love I Grissel, that my life
Shall end, when she doth end to be my wife.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.l: 'Tis well done.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Yet is my bosom burned up with desires,
To try my Grissel's patience, I'll put on
A wrinkled forehead, and turn both mine eyes,
Into two balls of fire, and clasp my hand
like to a mace of iron, to threaten death.
But Furio when that hand lifts up to strike,
It shall fly open to embrace my love,
Yet Grissel must not know this: all my words,
Shall smack of wormwood, all my deeds of gall,
My tongue shall jar, my heart be musical,
Yet Grissel must not know this?

div.stage: Enter Grissill.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.l: Not for me,

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Furio my trial is thy secrecy,
Yonder she comes: on goes this mask of frowns,
Tell her I am angry: men men try your wives,
Love that abides sharp tempests, sweetly thrives.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.l: My lord is angry.

sp.speaker: Gris.
sp.l: Angry? the heavens forfend: with whom? for what?
Is it with me?

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.l: Not me.

sp.speaker: Gris.
sp.l: May I presume,
To touch the vain of that sad discontent,
Which swells upon my dear lords angry brow?

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Away away,

sp.speaker: Gris.
sp.l: O chide me not away,
Your handmaid Grissel with unvexed thoughts,
And with an unrepining soul, will bear
The burden of all sorrows, of all woe,
Before the smallest grief should wound you so.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: I am not beholding to your love for this,
Woman I love thee not, thine eyes to mine
Are eyes of basilisks, they murder me.

sp.speaker: Gris.
sp.l: Suffer me to part hence, I'll tear them out,
Because they work such treason to my love.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Talk not of love I hate thee more than poison
That sticks upon the airs infected wings,
Exhaled up by the hot breath of the sun,
'tis for thy sake that speckled infamy,
Sits like a screech-owl on my honoured breast,
To make my subjects stare and mock at me,
They swear they'll never bend their awful knees,
To the base issue of the beggar womb,
'Tis for thy sake they curse me, rail at me,
Thinkst thou then I can love thee (O my soul)
Why didst thou build this mountain of my shame,
Why lie my joys buried in Grissel's name?

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: My gracious lord.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Call not me gracious lord,
See woman here hangs up thine ancestry,
The monuments of thy nobility,
This is thy russet gentry, coat, and crest
Thy earthen honours I will never hide,
Because this bridle shall pull in thy pride.

sp.speaker: Gris.
sp.l: Poor Grissel is not proud of these attires,
They are to me but as you livery,
And from your humble servant when you please,
You may take all this outside, which indeed
Is none of Grissel's, her best wealth is need,
I'll cast this gayness of, and be content
To wear this russet bravery of my own,
For that's more warm than this, I shall look old,
No sooner in course freeze then cloth of gold.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Spite of my soul she'll triumph over me.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.l: Your glove my lord,

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Cast down my glove again,
Stoop you for it, for I will have you stoop,
And kneel even to the meanest groom I keep.

sp.speaker: Gris.
sp.l: 'Tis but my duty if you'll have me stoop,
Even to your meanest groom my lord I'll stoop.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Furio how slovenly thou goest attired?

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.l: Why so my lord?

sp.speaker: Marq
sp.l: Look here thy shoes are both untied,
Grissel kneel you and tie them.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.l: Pardon me.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Quickly I charge you,

sp.speaker: Gris.
sp.l: Friend you do me wrong,
To let me hold my lord in wrath so long,
Stand still I'll kneel and tie them: what I do
Furio 'tis done to him and not to you. Tie them.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.l: 'Tis so.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: O strange o admiral patience,
I fear when Grissel's bones sleep in her grave,
The world a second Grissel ne'er will have,
Now get you in.

sp.speaker: Gris.
sp.l: I go my gracious lord.Exit

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Didst thou not here her sigh, did not one frown
Contract her beauteous forehead.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.l: I saw none

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Did not one drop fall down from sorrow's eyes,
To blame my heart for these her injuries?

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.l: Faith not a drop, I fear she'll frown on me,
For doing me service?

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Furio that I'll try,
My voice may yet o'ertake her: Grissel, Grissel?

div.stage: Enter Grissill.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.l: She comes at first call.

sp.speaker: Gris.
sp.l: Did my lord call?

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Woman I called thee not,
I said this slave was like to Grissel, Grissel,
And must you therefore come to torture me?
Nay stay here's a companion fit for you,
Thou vexest me, so doth this villain to,
But ere the sun to his highest throne ascend,
My indignation in his death shall end.

sp.speaker: Gris.
sp.l: O pardon him my lord, for mercy's wings
Bears round about the world the fame of Kings,
Temper your wrath I beg it on my knee,
forgive his fault though you'll not pardon me,

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Thank her.

sp.speaker: Fu.
sp.l: Thanks madam.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: I have not true power,
To wound thee with denial, o my Grissel,
How dear should I love thee,
Yea die to do thee good, but that my subjects
Upbraid me with thy birth, and call it base.
And grieve to see thy father and thy brother
Heaved up to dignities.

sp.speaker: Gris.
sp.l: O cast them down,
And send poor Grissel poorly home again,
High cedars fall, when low shrubs safe remain.Exit

div.stage: Enter at the same door Mario and Lepido.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: Fetch me a cup of wine.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.l: She's a saint sure.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: O Furio now I'll boast that I have found,
An angel upon earth: she shall be crowned
The empress of all women. Lepido?
Mario? what was she that passed by you?

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Your virtuous wife.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Call her not virtuous,
For I abhor her, did not her swollen eyes
Look red with hate or scorn? did she not curse
My name or Furio's name?

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: No my dear lord.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: For he and I railed at her, spit at her,
I'll burst her heart with sorrow, for I grieve
To see you grieve that I have wronged my state,
By loving one whose baseness now I hate.
Come faster if you can forbear Mario,
'Tis but her office: what she does to me,
She shall perform to any of you three,I'll drink

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: I am glad to see her pride thus trampled down

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Now serve Mario, then serve Lepido:
And as you bow to me, so bend to them.

sp.speaker: Gris.
sp.l: I'll not deny't to win a diadem.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: Your wisdom I commend that have thepower
To raise or throw down as you smile or lower.

sp.speaker: Gris.
sp.l: Your patience I commend that can abide,
To hear a flatterer speak yet never chide.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Hence, hence dare you control them whom I grace
Come not within my sight.

sp.speaker: Gris.
sp.l: I will obey,
And if you please, ne'er more behold the day. Exit.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Furio?

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.l: My lord,

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Watch her where she goes,
And mark how in her looks this trial shows.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.l: I will. Exit.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Mario, Lepido, I loathe this Grissel,
As sick men loathe the bitterest potion
Which the physician's hand holds out to them,
For god's sake frown upon her when she smiles,
For god's sake smile for joy to see her frown,
For god's sake scorn her, call her beggar's brat,
Torment her with your looks, your words your deeds,
My heart shall leap for joy, that her heart bleeds,
Wilt thou do this Mario?

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: If you say.
Mario, do this I must in it obey.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: I know you must, so Lepido must you
'Tis well; but counsel me what's best to do,
How shall I please my subjects? do but speak,
I'll do it though Grissel's heart in sunder break.

sp.speaker: Lepi.
sp.l: Your subjects do repine at nothing more,
Than to behold Janicola her father,
And her base brother lifted up so high.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: To banish them from court were policy.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: O rare, o profound wisdom, dear marie,
It forthwith shall be done, they shall not stay,
Though I may win by them a kingdom's sway,Exit

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: Mario laugh at this.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Why so I do.
Headlong I had rather fall to misery.
Then see a beggar raised to dignity. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Babulo singing with a boy after him.

sp.speaker: Bab.
sp.p: Boy how sits my rapier: la sol la sol. Etc.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: It hangs as even as a chandler's beam.

sp.speaker: Bab.
sp.p: Some of them deserve to hang upon a beam for that evenness, boy learn to give every man his due, give the hangman his due, for he's a necessary member.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: That's true, for he cuts of many wicked members.

sp.speaker: Bab.
sp.p: He's an excellent barber, he shaves most cleanly but page how dost thou like the court?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Prettily and so,

sp.speaker: Bab.
sp.p: Faith so do I prettily and so: I am weary of being a courtier boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: That you cannot be master, for you are but a courtier's man.

sp.speaker: Bab.
sp.p: Thou sayest true and thou art the courtier's man's boy, so thou art a courtier in decimo sexto in the least volume, or a courtier at the third hand, or a courtier by reversion, or a courtier three descents removed, or a courtier in minority or an under courtier or a courtier in posse, and I thy master in esse:

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: A posse an esse non este argumentum master,

sp.speaker: Bab.
sp.p: Thou hast to much wit to be so little, but imitation, imitation, is his good lord and master.

div.stage: Enter Janicola Laureo and Furio.

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.p: Banished from count, o what have we misdone?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: What have we done, we must be thus disgraced?

sp.speaker: Fu.
sp.p: I know not, but you are best pack, 'tis my lords will, and that's law, I must uncase you: your best course is to fall to your own trades.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: Sirrah, what art thou a broker?

sp.speaker: Fu.
sp.p: No, how then, I am a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Ba,
sp.p: Thou'rt a Jew, thou'rt a pagan: how dar'st thou leave them without a cloak for the rain, when his daughter, and his sister, and my mistress is the King's wife?

sp.speaker: Fu.
sp.p: Go look, sirrah fool, my condition is to ship you too.

sp.speaker: Bab.
sp.p: There's a ship of fools ready to hoist sail, they stay but for a good wind and your company: ha ha ha, I wonder (If all fools were banished) where thou wouldst take shipping.

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.p: Peace Babulo, we are banished from the court.

sp.speaker: Bab.
sp.p: I am glad, it shall case me of a charge here, as long as we have good clothes on one backs, 'tis no matter for our honesty, we'll live anywhere , and keep court in any corner.

div.stage: Enter Grissill.

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.l: O my dear Grissel.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: You from me are banished,
But ere you leave the court, o leave I pray
Your grief in Grissel's bosom, let my cheeks
Be watered with woes tears, for here and here,
And in the error of these wand'ring eyes,
Began your discontent: had not I been,
By nature painted thus: this had not been,
To leave the court and care be patient,
In your old cottage you shall find content.
Mourn not because these silks are ta'en away,
you'll seem more rich in a course gown of grey,

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.l: Will you be parking? when?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Friend what's thy name?

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.l: Furio my name is, what of that?

sp.speaker: Bab.
sp.p: Is thy name fury? thou art half hanged, for thou hast an ill name.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Thy looks are like thy name, thy name and looks approve thy nature to be violent.

sp.speaker: Gris.
sp.l: Brother forbear, he's servant to my lord.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: To him, m. spare him not an inch.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Princes are never pleased with subjects' sins,
But pity those whom they are sworn to smite,
And grieve as tender mothers when they beat,
With kind correction their unquiet babes -
So should their officers compassionate,
The misery of any wretch's state.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: I must obey my master, though indeed my heart (That seems hard) at their wrongs doth bleed. Pray get you gone, I say little, but you know my mind.

sp.speaker: Bab.
sp.p: Little said is soon amended, thou say'st but little, and that little will be mended soon indeed, that's never, and so the proverb stands in his full strength, power and virtue.

div.stage: Enter marquess, Mario and Lepido, and attendants.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.l: They will not go my lord.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Will they not go?
Away with them, expel them from our court,
Base wretches, is it wrong to ask mine own?
Think you that my affection to my wife,
Is greater than my love to public weal?
Do not my people murmur every hour,
That I have raised you up to dignities?
Do not lewd minstrels in their ribald runes,
Scoff at her birth, and descant on her dower?

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.l: Alas my lord, you knew her state before.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: I did, and from the bounty of my heart,
I robbed my wardrobe of all precious robes,
That she might shine in beauty like the sun,
And in exchange, I hung this russet gown,
And this poor pitcher for a monument,
Amongst my costliest gems: see here they hang,
Grissel look here, this gown is unlike to this?

sp.speaker: Gris.
sp.l: My gracious lord, I know full well it is.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: Grissel was as pretty a Grissel in the one as in the other.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: You have forgotten these rags, this water pot.

sp.speaker: Gris.
sp.l: With reverence of your highness I have not.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: Nor I, many a good mess of water gruel has that yielded us.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Yes, you are proud of these your rich attires.

sp.speaker: Gris.
sp.l: Never did pride keep pace with my desires.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Well, get you on, part briefly with your father.

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.l: Our parting shall be short, daughter farewell.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Our parting shall be short, sister farewell.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Our parting shall be short, Grissel farewell.

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.l: Remember thou didst live when thou wert poor,
And now thou dost but live, come son no more.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: See them without the palace Furio.

sp.speaker: Fu.
sp.l: Good, yet 'tis bad. Exeunt with Furio.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: Shall Furio see them out of the palace? do you turn us out of doors? you turn us out of doors then?

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.p: Hence with that fool, Mario drive him hence,

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: He shall not need, I am no ox nor ass, I can go without driving, for all his turning, I am glad of one thing.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.p: What's that Babulo?

sp.speaker: Bab.
sp.p: Marry that he shall never hit us ith' tooth with turning us, for 'tis not a good turn, follower I must cashier you: I must give over housekeeping, 'tis the fashion, farewell boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Marry farewell and be hanged.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: I am glad thou takest thy death so patiently, farewell my lord, adieu my lady, great was the wisdom of that tailor, that stitched me in motley, for he's a fool that leaves basket making to turn courtier: I see my destiny dogs me: at first I was a fool (For I was born an innocent) than I was a traveller, and then a basketmaker, and then a courtier, and now I most turn basketmaker and fool again, the one I am sworn to, but the fool I bestow upon the world, for stultorum plena sunt ominia adieu, adieu. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Farewell simplicity, part of my shame farewell, now lady what say you of their exile?

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: Whatever you think good, I'll not term vile,
By this rich burden in my worthless womb,
Your handmaid is so subject to your will,
That nothing which you do, to her seems ill.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I am glad you are so patient, get you in,Exit Gr.
Thy like will never be, never hath been.
Mario, Lepido?

sp.speaker: Mario Lepi.
sp.l: My gracious lord.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: The hand of poverty held down your states,
As it did Grissel's, and as her I raised,
To shine in greatness sphere, so did mine eye,
Through gilt beams of your births, therefore methinks
Your soul should sympathize, and you should know,
What passions in my Grissel's bosom flow,
Faith tell me your opinions of my wife?

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: She is as virtuous and as patient,
As innocent, as patience itself.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: She merits much of love, little of hate,
Only in birth she is unfortunate.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Ay, ay, the memory of that mirth doth kill me,
She is with child you see, her travail past,
I am determined she shall leave the court,
And live again with old Janicola.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Therein you show true wisdom.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Do I indeed?
Dear friends it shall be done, I'll have you two
Rumour that presently, to the wide ears
Of that newes-loving-beast the multitude,
Go tell them for their sakes this shall be done.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: With wings we fly.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: Swifter than time we run. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Begone then: o these times, these impious times,
How swift is mischief? with what nimble feet
Doth envy gallop to do injury?
They both confess my Grissel's innocence,
They both admire her wondrous patience,
Yet in their malice and to flatter me,
Headlong they run to this impiety.
O what's this world, but a confused throng
Of fools and mad men, crowding in a thrust
To shoulder out the wise, trip down the just.
But I will try by self experience,
And shun the vulgar sentence of the base,
If I find Grissel strong in patience,
These flatterers shall be wounded with disgrace,
And whilst verse lives, the fame shall never die,
Of Grissel's patience, and her constancy. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Urcenze and Onophrio at several doors, and farnezie in the midst.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.p: Onophrio and Urcenze early met, every man take his stand, for there comes a most rich purchase of mirth: Emulo with his hand in a fair scarf, and Julia

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.p: He'll strip himself out of his shirt anon, for god's sake step in.

sp.speaker: Emu.
sp.p: My opinion is I shall never recuperate the legitimate office of this member my arm.

sp.speaker: All 3.
sp.p: Signior Emulo.

sp.speaker: Emu
sp.p: Sweet and accomplished signiors.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.p: Ha ha, madame you had a pitiful hand with this fool, but see he is recovered.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p: But servant where is your other hand?

sp.speaker: Ono.
sp.p: See sweet mistress one is my prisoner.

sp.speaker: Vrc.
sp.p: The other I have ta'en up with the fine finger.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Look in his scarf Farneze for another, he has a third hand, and 'tis pitifully wounded he tells me, pitifully, pitifully.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.p: Wounded, o palpable, come a demonstration of it.

sp.speaker: Ono.
sp.p: Give him your larded cloak signior to stop his mouth, for he will undo you with lies.

sp.speaker: Vrc.
sp.p: Come signior, one fine lie now to apparel all these former, in some light sarsenet robe of truth: none, none, in this mint?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Fie servant, is your accomplished courtship nothing but lies:

sp.speaker: Ono.
sp.p: Fie signior, no music in your mouth, but battles, yet a mere milksop.

sp.speaker: Vrc.
sp.p: Fie Emulo, nothing but wardrobe, yet hear all your trunks of suits?

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.p: Fie signior, a scarce about your neck, yet will not hang yourself to hear all this?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Servant I discharge you my service, I'll entertain no braggarts.

sp.speaker: Ono.
sp.p: Signior, we discharge you the court, we'll have no gulls in our company.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.p: Abram we cashier you our company, we must have no minions at court.

sp.speaker: Emu.
sp.p:
O patience be thou my fortification: Italy
thou spurnest me for uttering that nutriment, which I sucked from thee.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: How Italy? away you idiot: Italy infects you not, but your own diseased spirits: Italy? out you froth, you scum, because your soul is mud, and that you have breathed in Italy, you'll say Italy have defiled you: away you bore, thou wilt wallow in mire in the sweetest country in the world.

sp.speaker: Emu.
sp.l: I cannot conceit this rawness: Italy farewell, Italians adieu.
A virtuous soul abhors to dwell with you. Exit.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ha ha ha:Laugh.

div.stage: Enter marquess and sir Owen.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p: Peace servants, here comes the Duke my brother.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Lo cousin here they be: are ye here gentlemen?
And Julia you too? then I'll call your eyes,
To testify, that to sir Meredith,
I do deliver here four sealed bonds:
Coz have a care to them, it much behooves you,
For gentlemen, within this parchment lies,
Five thousand ducats payable to him,
Just fourteen days before next Pentecost,
Coz it concerns you, therefore keep them safe.

sp.speaker: Owen.
sp.p: Fugh, her warrant her shall log them ub from sun and moon, and seven stars too I hobe, but harg you cozen marquess.

sp.speaker: Marq
sp.p: Now, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Ow.
sp.p: A poor on it 'tis scald matter, well, well pray cozen marquess, use her latie Grissel a good teale better, for as God udge me, you heard sir Owen out a cry by maging her sad and proved so, see you?

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.p: Hurt you? what harm or good reap you thereby?

sp.speaker: Owen.
sp.p: Harm, yes by god's lid, a poggy teale of harm, for loog you cozen, and cozen Julia, and shentlemen awl, (For awl is to know her wife's case) you know her tag to wife the widow Gwenthyan.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.p: True cousin and she's a virtuous gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: On.
sp.p: One of the patientest ladies in the world.

sp.speaker: Vrc.
sp.p: She's wondrous beautiful and wondrous kind.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.p: She's the quietest woman that ere I knew, for good heart, she'll put up any thing.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Cousin I am proud that you are sped so well.

sp.speaker: Ow.
sp.p: Are you? by God so are not I, I'll tell you what cozen marquess, you awl know her well, you know her face is liddle fair and smug, but her has a tongue goes jingle jangle, jingle jangle, better and worse than pelles when her house is a fire: patient? ha ha sir Owen shall tag her heels and run to Wales, and her play the tiuell so out a cry terrible a pogs on her la.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Why cozen what are her qualities that you so commend her?

sp.speaker: Ow.
sp.p: Commend her? no by God not I, ha ha: is know her qualities better and better, fore I commend her: but Gwenthian is worse and worse out a cry, owe out a cry worse, out of awl cry, she's feared to be made fool as Grissel is, and as God udge me, her mag fine pobbie fool of sir Owen, her shide and shide, and prawle and scold, by God and scratch terrible sometime, owe and haid her will do what her can, ha ha ha, and sir Owen were handsome pachcler again, pray cozen marquess tag some order in Grissel, or fetch sir Owen to mag Gwenthyan's quiet and tame her.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: To tame her? that I'll teach you presently,
You had no sooner spoke the word of taming,
But mine eye met a speedy remedy,
See cozen here's a plot where osiers grow,
The ground belongs to old Janicula
(My Grissel's father) come sir Meredith,
Take out your knife cut three and so will I,
so, keep yours cozen let them be safe laid up,
These thrée (Thus wound together) I'll preserve.

sp.speaker: Ow.
sp.p: What shall her do now with these? peat and knog her Gwenthian. Enter Mario.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: You shall not take such counsel from my lips,
How now Mario? what news brings thee hither in such quick haste?

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: Your wife (My gracious lord)
Is now delivered of two beauteous twins,
A son and daughter.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Take that for thy pains,
Not for the joy that I conceive thereby,
For Grissel is not gracious in the eye
Of those that love me, therefore I must hate
Those that do make my life unfortunate.
And that's my children: must I not Mario?
Thou bowest thy knee, well, well I know thy mind,
Virtue in villains can no succour find,
A son and daughter? I by them will prove,
My Grissel's patience better, and her love:
Come Julia, come Onophrio, coz farewell,
Reserve those wands, these three I'll bear away,
When I require them back, then will I show
How easily a man may tame a shrew. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ow.
sp.p: Ha ha ha, tame a shrew, owe 'tis out a cry terrible hard, and more worse than tame a mad pull, but whad mean her cozen to mag her cut her wands? ha ha, God udge me 'tis fine knag, I see her knavery now, 'tis to pang Gwenthyan's podie and she mag a noise and prabble: is not so? by god's lid so, and Gwenthian, sir Owen will knog you before her abide such horrible do. Enter Gwenthian and Rice.God's lid here her comes. Terdawgh Gwenthian Terdawgh.

sp.speaker: Gwe.
sp.p: Terdawgh whee, sir Owen Terdawgh whee.

sp.speaker: Owen.
sp.p: Owe, looge here, fine wands Gwenthyan, is not?

sp.speaker: Gwe.
sp.p: Rees tag them and preag them in pieces.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: What say you forsooth?

sp.speaker: Gwe.
sp.p: What say you forsooth? you saucy knave, must her tell her once, and twice, and thrice, and four times, what to do? preag these wands.

sp.speaker: Ow.
sp.p: Rees is better preak Rees his pate: here Rees carry her home.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Would I were at gallows, so I were not here:

sp.speaker: Gwen.
sp.p: Do and her tear, do and her tear, see you now, what shall her do with wands? peat Gwenthyan? podie and mag Gwenthyan put her finger in me hole: ha, by God by God, is scratch her eyes out that judge her, that tawg to her, that loog on her, marg you that sir Owen?

sp.speaker: Owen.
sp.p: Yes, her marg her, Rees pray marg her lady?

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Not I sir she'll set her marks on me then.

sp.speaker: Gwen.
sp.p: Is prade? is prade? go too Rees, I'll Rees her, you tawg you.

sp.speaker: Owen.
sp.p: Pray Gwenthyan be patient, as her cousin Grissel is.

sp.speaker: Gwe.
sp.p: Grissel owe? owe? Grissel? no, no, no, no. her shall not mag Gwenthian such ninny pobbie fool as Grissel, I say preage her wands.

sp.speaker: Owen.
sp.p: Cod's plude is pought her to peat dust out of her cloag and parrels.

sp.speaker: Gwe.
sp.p: Peate her cloag and parrels? fie, fie, fie, 'tis lie sir Owen 'tis lie.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Your worship may stab her, she gives you the lie.

sp.speaker: Ow.
sp.p: Peace Rees, go to, I pought them indeed to mag her horse run and go a mighty teale of pace, pray let Rees tag her in good Gwenthian?

sp.speaker: Gwen.
sp.p: Rees bear in her wands because sir Owen beg so gently.

sp.speaker: Owen.
sp.p: Go Rees, go lock them up in a pox or shest, go.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: You shall not need to bid me go, for I'll run. Exit.

sp.speaker: Owen.
sp.p: I pought them for her horse indeed, for here was her cousin marquess and prought her ponds and scribblings here for her money: Gwenthyan pray keep her ponds and keep her wisely: sirrah Gwenthyan is tell her prave news, Grissel is prought to bed of liddle gentleman and gentlewoman: (Is glad out a cry speag her fair) yes truly Grissel is prought a-bed .

sp.speaker: Gwen.
sp.p: Grissel's no podie but Grissel's? what care I for Grissel: I say if sir Owen love Gwenthyan, shall not love Grissel nor marquess so, see you now?

sp.speaker: Ow.
sp.p: God udge me, not love her cozen? is shealous? owe is fine trig, not love her cozen? God udge me her will, and hang herself, see you now?

sp.speaker: Gwe.
sp.p: Hang herself, owe, owe, owe, Gwenthyan's tother husband is scawrne to say hang herself: hang herself? owe owe, owe owe.

sp.speaker: Ow.
sp.p: God's plude, what cannot get by prawles, is get by owe, owe owe, is terrible lady, pray be peace, and cry no more owe, owe, owe, tawsone Gwenthyan's, God udge me is very fury.

sp.speaker: Gwen.
sp.p: O mon Lago, mon due, hang Gwenthyan's?

sp.speaker: Ow.
sp.p: Adologo whee Gwenthyan bethogh, en thonigh, en moyen due.

sp.speaker: Gw.
sp.p: Ne vetho en thonigh, cna wathe gethla tee, hang Gwenthyan's?

sp.speaker: Owen.
sp.p: Sir Owen shall say no more hang herself, be out a cry still and her shall pie her new card to ride in, and two new fine horses, and more plew coats and padges ta follow her heels, see you now?

sp.speaker: Gwen.
sp.p: But will her say no more hang herself?

div.stage: Enter rice.

sp.speaker: Ow.
sp.p: O no more, as God udge me no more, pray leave, owe, owe, owe.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Tannekin the fide hath brought your rebato, it comes to three pound.

sp.speaker: Ow.
sp.p: What a pestilence is this for Gwenthyan?

sp.speaker: Gwe.
sp.p: For her neg, is called repatoes, Gwenthian wear it here, is't not prave?

sp.speaker: Owen.
sp.p: Brave? yes is prave, 'tis repatoes I warrant her: I patoes money out a cry, yes 'tis prave, Rees the preece? Rees the preece?

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: The froe sir says five pound.

sp.speaker: Owen.
sp.p: Ha ha ha, pound, Gwenthyan pray do not pie it.

sp.speaker: Gwen.
sp.p: By God udge me her shall pie it.

sp.speaker: Owen.
sp.p: God udge me her shall not.

sp.speaker: Gwen.
sp.p: Shall not? Rees tag her away, I say her shall and wear it pie and pie.

sp.speaker: Owen.
sp.p: Then mag a pobbie fool of sir Owen indeed: god's plude shall? I say shall not: five pound for puble, for patoes: here there, so tag it now, wear it now powte her neg, shall pridle sir Owen ha?

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: O rare sir Owen, ah precious knight, o rare sir Owen.

sp.speaker: Gwe.
sp.p: Out you rascals, you prade and prade, I'll prade your nieces.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: O rare madam, o precious madam, oh God, oh God, oh God, o.Exit.

sp.speaker: Gwe.
sp.p: Is domineer now, you tear her ruffs and repatoes, you preak her ponds? I'll tear as good ponds, and better too, and better too.

sp.speaker: Ow.
sp.p: Owe Gwenthyan, cod's plude is five thousand ducats, hold hold hold, a pogs on her pride, what has her done?

sp.speaker: Gw.
sp.p: Go loog, is now paid for her repatoes, I'll have her wills and desires, I'll teadge her pridle her lady: Catho crogge, ne vetho, en thlonigh gna wathee gnathlatee. Exit

sp.speaker: Owen.
sp.p:
A breath vawer or no tee: pridle her, sir Owen is pridled I warrant: widows (Were better god's plude marry whore) were better be hanged and quarter, then marry widows as God udge me: sir Owen fall on her knees, and pray God to tag her to her mercy, or else put better mind in her lady: awl Prittish shentlemans tag
heed how her marry fixen widow.
sp.l: Sir Owen ap Meredith can rightly tell,
A shrew's sharp tongue is terrible as hell. Exit.

div.stage: Enter marquess and Furio with an infant in his arms.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Did she not see thee when thou tookest it up?

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.l: No, she was fast asleep .

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Give me this blessed burden, pretty fool
With what an amiable look it sleeps,
And in that slumber how it sweetly smiles,
And in that smile how my heart leaps for joy:
Furio I'll turn this circle to a cradle,
To rock my dear babe: a great Roman lord,
Taught his young son to ride a hobby-horse.
Then why should I think scorn to dandle mine:
Furio behold it well, to whom is't like?

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.l: You, there's your nose and black eyebrows.

div.stage: Enter Mario.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Thou dost but flatter me, here comes Mario,
I know Mario will not flatter me,
Mario, thy opinion, view this child,
Doth not his lips, his nose, his forehead,
And every other part resemble mine?

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: So like my lord, that the nice difference,
Would stay the judgement of the curious't eye.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: And yet methinks I am not half so brown.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: Indeed your cheeks bear a more lively colour

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Furio, play thou the nurse, handle it softly.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.l: One were better get a dozen then nurse one.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Mario step to Grissel she's asleep ,
Her white hand is the pillar to those cares,
Which I ungently lodged within her head,
Steal thou the other child and bring it hither,
If Grissel be awake and strive with thee,
bring it perforce, nor let her know what hand,
Hath robbed her of this other, haste Mario.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: I fly my gracious lord. Exit.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Run flattery, because I did blaspheme and call it brown,
This parasite cried (Like an echo) brown.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.l: The child is fair my lord, you were ne'er so fair.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: I know 'tis fair, I know 'tis wondrous fair,
Dear pretty infant let me with a kiss,
Take that dishonour off, which the foul breath
Of a profane slave, laid upon thy cheeks;
Had but I said my boy's a blackamoor,
He would have damned himself and so have sworn.

div.stage: Enter Grissill and Mario with a child.

sp.speaker: Gris.
sp.l: Give me mine infant, where's my other babe?
You cannot play the nurse, your horrid eyes
Will fright my little ones and make them cry,
Your tongue's too ruff to chime a lullaby:
'Tis not the pleasure of my lord I know,
To load me with such wrong.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: No, I unload you. Scoffingly.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Give her her child Mario and yet stay,
Furio hold thou them both, Grissel forbear,
You are but nurse to them they are not thine.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: I know my gracious lord they are not mine,
I am but their poor nurse I must confess,
Alas let not a nurse be pitiless.
To see the cold air make them look thus bleak,
Makes me shed tears because they cannot speak.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: If they could speak, what think you they would say?

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: That I in all things will your will obey.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Obey it then in silence: shall not I
bestow what is mine own, as likes me best?
Deliver me these brats: come press me down,
With weighty infamy: here is a load
Of shame, of speckled shame: oh God how heavy
An armful of dishonour is? here's two,
Grissel for this I'll thank none else but you,
Which way soe'er I turn I meet a face,
That makes my cheeks blush at mine own disgrace.
This way or this way, never shall mine eye
Look thus, or thus: but (O me) presently,
(Take them for God's sake Furio) presently
I shall spend childish tears: true tears indeed,
That thus I wrong my babes and make her bleed,
Go Grissel get you in.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: I go my lord.
Farewell sweet sweet dear babes, so you were free,
Would all the world's cares might be thrown on me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Ha, ha, why this is pleasing harmony.

sp.speaker: Fu.
sp.l: My lord they'll wrawl, what shall I do with them?

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Tell her thou must provide a nurse for them
Comes she not back Mario?

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: No my lord.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Tush, tush, it cannot be but she'll return,
I know her bosom bears no marble heart,
I know, a tender mother cannot part,
With such a patient soul, from such sweet souls,
She stands and watches sure, and sure the weeps,
To see my seeming flinty breast, Mario
Withdraw with me: Furio stay thou here still,
If she return, seem childish, and deny
To let her kiss or touch them.Exeunt

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Faith not I: I have not such a heart, and she ask to touch them. I'll deny it because I'll obey my lord, yet she shall kiss and touch them to, because I'll please my lady: alas, alas, pretty fools I love you well but I would you had a better nurse.

div.stage: Enter Grissill stealingly.

sp.speaker: Gris.
sp.l: A better nurse: seekest thou a better nurse?
A better nurse then whom?

sp.speaker: Fu.
sp.l: Then you, away.

sp.speaker: Gris.
sp.l: I am their mother I must not away,
Look, look, good Furio look they smile on me,
I know poor hearts they fear to smile on thee,
I prithee let me have them.

sp.speaker: Fu.
sp.l: Touch them not.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: I pray thee let me touch them.

sp.speaker: Fu.
sp.l: No: hands off.

sp.speaker: Gri.
