sp.l: I pray thee gentle Furio let me kiss them.

sp.speaker: Fu,
sp.l: Not one kiss for a King's crown:

sp.speaker: Gris.
sp.l: Must I not kiss my babes: must I not touch them?
Alas what sin so vile hath Grissel done
That thus she should be vexed? not kiss my infants?
Who taught thee to be cruel gentle churl,
What must thou do with them?

sp.speaker: Fu.
sp.l: Get them a nurse.

sp.speaker: Gris.
sp.l: A nurse alack, what nurse? where must she dwell

sp.speaker: Fu.
sp.l: I must not tell you: till I know myself,

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: For god's sake who must nurse them do but name her,
And I will swear those fiery eyes do smile,
And I will swear that which none else will swear,
That thy grim brows, do mercy's livery wear,

sp.speaker: Fu.
sp.l: Choose you.

div.stage: Enter marquess, standing aside.

sp.speaker: Gris.
sp.l: O God, o God, might Grissel have her choice
My babes should not be scared with thy devil's voice.
Thou get a nurse for them? they can abide,
To taste no milk but mine, come, come I'll chide,
In faith you cruel man, I'll chide indeed,
If I grow angry.

sp.speaker: Fu.
sp.l: Do do I care not.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: To chide and curse thy lord thou hast more need

sp.speaker: Gris.
sp.l: Wilt thou not tell me who shall be their nurse?

sp.speaker: Fu.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Gris.
sp.l: Wilt thou not let me kiss them?

sp.speaker: Fu
sp.l: No I say.

sp.speaker: Gris.
sp.l: I prithee let my tears, let my bowed knees,
Bend thy obdurate heart, see here's a fountain,
Which heaven into this alabaster bowels,
Instilled to nourish them: man they'll cry,
And blame thee that this runs so lavishly,
Here's milk for both my babes two breasts for two.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Poor babes I weep to see what wrong I do.

sp.speaker: Gris.
sp.l: I pray thee let them suck I am most meet,
To play their nurse: they'll smile and say 'tis sweet,
Which streams from hence, if thou dost bear them hence,
My angry breasts will swell, and as mine eyes
Lets fall salt drops, with these white nectar tears,
They will be mixed: this sweet will then be brine,
They'll cry I'll chide and say the sin is thine.

sp.speaker: Fu.
sp.l: Mine arms ache mightily.
And my heart aches.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: And so doth mine: sweet sounds this discord makes.

sp.speaker: Fu.
sp.p: Here madam take one, I am weary of both, touch it and kiss it to, it's a sweet child, I would I were rid of my misery, for I shall drown my heart, with my tears that fall inward.

sp.speaker: Gris.
sp.l: O this is gently done this is my boy.
My first born care: thy feet that never felt ground,
Have travelled longest in this land of woe,
This world's wilderness, and hast most need,
Of my most comfort: o I thank thee Furio,
I know I should transform thee with my tears,
And melt thy adamantive heart like wax,
What wrong shall these have to be ta'en from me,
Mildly entreat their nurse to touch them mildly,
For my soul tells me, that my honoured lord,
does but to try poor Grissel's constancy,
He's full of mercy justice, full of love.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: My cheeks do glow with shame to hear her speak,
Should I not weep for joy my heart would break,
And yet a little more I'll stretch my trial.
Mario, Lepido?

sp.speaker: Both
sp.l: My gracious lord?

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: You shall be witness of this open wrong,
I gave straight charge, she should not touch these brats,
Yet has she tempted with lascivious tears,
The heart of Furio, see she dandles them,
Take that child from her: stay, stay, I'll commend,
That pity in thee which I'll reprehend.

sp.speaker: Fu.
sp.l: Do.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Dare you thus contradict our straight command
But here's a trusty groom, out hypocrite,
I shall do justice wrong to let thee breath,
For disobeying me.

sp.speaker: Gris.
sp.l: My gracious lord,

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Tempt me not Siren, since you are so loving,
Hold you take both your children, get you gone,
Derobe her of these rich abiliments,
Take down her hat, her pitcher and her gown,
And as she came to me in beggary,
So drive her to her fathers.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: My dear lord.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Vex me not good Mario if you woo me,
(Or if you shed one tear) to pity her,
Or if by any drift you succour her,
You lose my favour everlastingly,

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: We must obey since there's no remedy,

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: You must be villains there's no remedy,
Mario, Lepido, you two shall help,
To bear her children home.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: It shall not need I can bear more.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Thou bearest too much indeed.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: Come, come sweet lambs we'll laugh and live content
Though from the court we live in banishment,
These rich attires are for your mother fit,
But not your nurse, therefore I'll off with it.

sp.speaker: Marq
sp.l: Away with her I say.

sp.speaker: Gris.
sp.l: Away, away?
Nothing but that cold comfort we'll obey,
Heaven smile upon my lord with gracious eye,

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Drive her hence Lepido.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: Good madam hence.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: Thus tyranny oppresseth innocence,
Thy looks seem heavy, but thy heart is light,
For villains laugh when wrong oppresseth right. Run to him
Must we then be driven hence: o see my lord,
Sweet pretty fools they both smiled at that word.
They smile as who should say indeed indeed,
Your tongue cries hence, but your heart's not agreed,
Can you thus part from them? in truth I know,
Your true love cannot let these infants go.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: She'll triumph over me do what I can.

div.stage: Turns from her.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: Good madam hence.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: O send one gracious smile
Before we leave this place: turn not away,
Do but look back, let us but once more see
Those eyes, whose beams shall breathe new souls in three,
It is enough now we'll depart in joy,
Nay be not you so cruel, should you two
Be thus driven hence, trust me I'd pity you.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Disrobe her presently.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: It shall be done.

sp.speaker: Grissi.
sp.l: To work some good deed thus you would not run. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: O Grissel in large characters of gold,
thy virtuous sacred fame shall be enrolled,
Tell me thy judgement Furio of my wife?

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: I think my lord she's a true woman, for she loves her children, a rare wife, for she loves you, (I believe you'll hardly find her match) and I think she's more than a woman, because she conqueres all wrongs by patience.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yet once more will I try her, presently
I'll have thee go to old Ianicola's,
And take her children from her, breed some doubt,
(By speeches) in her, that her eyes shall never
Behold them more: bear them to Pavia,
Commend us to our brother, say from us,
That we desire him with all kind respect,
To nurse the infants, and withal conceal,
Their parentage from any mortal ear,
I charge thee on thy life reveal not this,
I charge thee on thy life, be like thy name,
(When thou com'st to her) rough and furious.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Well, I will: it's far from Saluce to Pavia, the children will cry, I have no teats you know, 'twere good you thought upon it.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: There's gold.

sp.speaker: Fu.
sp.l: That's good.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Provide them nurses.

sp.speaker: Fu.
sp.l: That's better, I will and I can. Exit Furio.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Away, though I dare trust thy secrecy,
Yet will I follow thee in some disguise,
And try thy faith, and Grissel's constancy:
If thou abide unblemished, than I swear,
A have found two wonders that are seldom rise,
A trusty servant, and a patient wife. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Janicola and Laureo, with burdens of osiers.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Father how fare you?

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.l: Very well my son,
this labour is a comfort to my age,
The marquess hath to me been merciful,
In sending me from courtly delicates,
To taste the quiet of this country life.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Call him not merciful, his tyranny
Exceeds the most inhuman.

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.l: Peace my son,
I thought by learning thou hadst been made wise,
But I perceive it puffeth up thy soul,
Thou takest a pleasure to be counted just,
And kick against the faults of mighty men:
O 'tis in vain, the earth may even as well
Challenge the potter to be partial,
For forming it to sundry offices:
Alas the error of ambitious fools,
How frail are all their thoughts, how faint, how weak?
Those that do strive to justle with the great,
Are certain to be bruised, or soon to break.
Come, come mell with our osiers, here let's rest,
This is old homely home, and that's still best.

div.stage: Enter Babulo with a bundle of osiers in one arm and a child in another, Grissill after him with another child.

sp.speaker: Bab.
sp.p: Hush, hush, hush, hush, and I dance mine own child and I dance mine own child, etc.: ha ha, whoop old master, so ho ho, look here, and I dance mine own child, etc.: here's sixteen pence a week, and sixteen pence a week, eight groats, soap and candle, I met her in osier grove, crying hush, hush, hush, hush: I thought it had been some beggar woman, because of her pitcher, for you know they bear such household stuff, to put drink and porridge together, and I dance mine, etc.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: O father now forswear all patience,
Grissel comes home to you in poor array,
Grissel is made a drudge, a castaway.

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.l: Grissel is welcome home to poverty,

div.stage: The song.

lg.l: Golden slumbers kiss your eyes,
Smiles awake you when you rise:
Sleep pretty wantons do not cry,
And I will sing a lullaby,
Rock them rock them lullaby.
Care is heavy therefore sleep you,
You are care and care must keep you:
Sleep pretty wantons do not cry,
And I will sing a lullaby,
Rock them rock them lullaby.

div.stage: Enter Furio and marquess aloof disguised with baskets.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Leave singing.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: We may choose, grandsire sol fa once more, we'll alla mire him, and he we wail in woe, and who can hinder us?

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Sirrah scholar read there, it's a commission for me to take away these children.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: Nay then you're welcome, there's four groats, and here's four more.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: To take away my children gentle Furio,
Why must my babes bear this ungentle doom?

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.l: Go look.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: O misery, oh most accursed time,
When to be foes to guilt is held a crime,
Sister this fiend must bear your infants hence.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Good Grissel bear all wrongs withpatience.Weeps

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: Good father let true patience cure all woe,
You bid me be content, o be you so.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Father why do you weep?

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.l: What can I do,
Though her he punish, he might pity you.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Let's fret and curse the marquess cruelly.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: I by my troth that's a good way, we may well do it, now we are out of his hearing.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: Must I then be divorced? and lose this treasure,
I must and am content, since 'tis his pleasure,
I pray thee tell we whither they must go?

sp.speaker: Fu.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: Art thou commanded to conceal the place?

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.l: I.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: Then will not I inquire, thou dost but jest
I know thou must not rob me, 'tis to try
If I love them: no, no, here I read,
That which strikes blind mine eyes, makes my heart bleed,
Farewell, farewell, dear souls, adieu adieu,
Your father sends and I must part from you,
I must o god I must, must is for Kings,
And lo obedience for lo underlings.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: He shall not hale them thus, keep them perforce,
This slave looks on them with a murdering eye.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: No, he shall not have them, knock out his brains, and save the little hop a my thumbs.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Do if you dare.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: How now my hearts, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Fu.
sp.l: What carest thou.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: This is poor Grissel, wife unto our Duke,
And these her children, thus he sends her home,
And thus he sends a serpent to devour,
Their precious lives he brings commission,
To hale them hence, but whither none can tell.

sp.speaker: Gris.
sp.l: Forbear, forbear.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Take them from him perforce,
Are these his children?

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: So she says.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Two sweet ducks, and is this his wife?

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Yes, he has line with her.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: A pretty soul, sirrah thou wilt be hanged for this.

sp.speaker: Fu.
sp.l: Hang thyself.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Beat him, but first take these two from his arms,
I am a basket maker, and I swear
I'll die before he bear away the babes.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: O rare, cry prentices and clubs, the corporation cannot be () sirrah set down thy baskets and to't pell-mell .

sp.speaker: Fu.
sp.p: Would I were rid of my office?

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: What will you do, drive this rash fellow hence?

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.p: The marquess is a tyrant and does worng.

sp.speaker: Gri ▪
sp.p: I would not for the world that he should hear thee.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I would not for ten worlds but hear my Grissel.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: A tyrant, no he's mercy even herself,
Justice in triumph rides in his two eyes,
Take heed how thou profanest high deities:
Go Furio, get thee gone: good father help me
To guard my dear lords servant from this place,
I know he'll do my pretty babes no harm,
For see Furio looks gently: o get thee gone,
Pity sits on thy cheeks, but God can tell,
My heart says my tongue lies, farewell farewell.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.p: Stay sirrah take thy purse.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: I let none fall.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: Half part.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: A purse of gold Furio is fallen from thee.

sp.speaker: Fu.
sp.p: It's none of mine, sirrah basketmaker, if my arms were not full, thou should have thy hands full: farewell Grissel, if thou never see thy children more, curse me, if thou dost see them again, thank God, adieu. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: Farewell and be hanged.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: I will thank God for all, why should I grieve,
To lose my children? no no, I ought rather
Rejoice, because they are born to their father.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: Daughter, here's nothing in this purse but gold.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p:
So much the better, master we'll quickly turn
it into silver.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: This purse that fellow did let fall, run run,
Carry it him again, run Babulo,
Away with it, 'tis laid to do us wrong.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Try all their golden baits, stay never run,
They can do no more wrong than they have done.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: What ails my Grissel? comfort my child.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: I'll fetch rosa solis.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Poor soul her grief burns inward, yet her tongue
Is loath to give it freedom: I do wrong,
O Grissel I do wrong thee and, lament,
That for my sake thou feelest this languishment.
I came to try a servant and a wife,
Both have I proved true, that purse of gold I brought,
And let if fall of purpose to relieve her,
Well may I give her gold that so much grieve her,
As I came in by stealth, so I'll away,
Joy has a tongue, but knows not what to say. Exit.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: So father I am well, I am well indeed,
I should do wondrous ill, should I repine,
At my babe's loss for they are none of mine.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I am glad thou takest this wound so patiently.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: Whoop whither is my brother basketmaker gone: ha let me see, I smell a rat, sneaked hence and never take leave, either he's a crafty knave, or else he dogs Furio to bite him, for when a quarrel enters into a trade it serves seven years before it be free.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Let him be whom he will, he seemed our friend,
Grissel lay up this gold 'tis Furio's sure,
Or it may be thy lord did give it him,
To let it fall for thee, but keep it safe,
If he disdain to love thee as a wife,
His gold shall not buy food to nourish thee,
Grissel come in, time swiftly runs away,
The greatest sorrow hath an ending day. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Gwenthyan and Rice, she meanly, he like a cook.

sp.speaker: Gwen.
sp.p: Rees, lay her table, and set out her fittailes, and preades, and wines, and ale, and pear, and salt for her guess.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Yes forsooth my lady but what shall I do with all yonder beggars?

sp.speaker: Gwe.
sp.p: Send out the peggers into her lady, go.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: How? the beggars in, we shall have a lousy feast madam. Exit Rees.

sp.speaker: Gwen.
sp.p: You rascals prate no more, but fetch them in: shall pridle sir Owen a good teale well enough, is warrant her. Sir Owen is gone to bid her cozen marquess and a meiny to dine at her house, but Gwenthyan shall kive her dinner I warrant her, for peggers shall have all her meat.

div.stage: Enter Rees with a company of beggars: a table is set with meat.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Come my hearts, troop, troop, every man follow his leader, here's my lady.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: God bless your ladyship, God bless your ladyship.

sp.speaker: Gwen.
sp.p: I thang you my good peggers, Rees pring stools, side awl down, Rees pring more meat.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Here madam, I'll set it on, take't off who will.

sp.speaker: Beg.
sp.p: Let us alone for that, my lady shall we scramble or eat mannerly?

sp.speaker: Gwen.
sp.p: Peggers I hobe have no manners, but first hear me pray you now, and then fall to out a cry.

sp.speaker: Beg.
sp.p: Peace hear my lady, Jacke-mumble-crust steal no penny loaves.

sp.speaker: Gwen.
sp.p: Peggers, awl you know sir Owen?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Passing well, passing well, God bless his worship.

sp.speaker: 1 Beg.
sp.p: Madam, we know him as well as a beggar knows his dish.

sp.speaker: Gwe.
sp.p: Awl these fittels is made for cousin marquess: sir Owen is gone to fetch him, but sir Owen has anger her lady.

sp.speaker: 1 Beg.
sp.p: More shame for him, he's not a knight, but a knitter of caps for it.

sp.speaker: Gwe.
sp.p: Sir Owen has anger her lady, and therefore her lady is anger sir Owen

sp.speaker: 1 Beg.
sp.p: Make him a cuckold madam, and upon that I drink to you: helter-skelter here rogues, top and top gallant, pell-mell , hufty-tufty , hem, God save the Duke, and a fig for the hangman.

sp.speaker: Gwen.
sp.p: Rees fetch wine and pears enough, and fall to pegger, and eat awl her sheer, and tomineere, see you now, pray do.

div.stage: A drunken feast, they quarrel and grow drunk, and pocket up the meat, the dealing of cans like a set a maw. Exit Rees.

sp.speaker: Gwe.
sp.p: Nay I pray peggers be quiet, tag your meats, you have trinkes enough I see, and get you home now good peggers.

sp.speaker: 1 Beg.
sp.p: Come your rogues, let's go tag and rag, cut and long tail, I am victualled for a month, God bye madame, pray God sir Owen and you may fall out every day: is there any harm in this now? heigh tri-lill, give the dog a loaf, fill the tother pot you whore and god save the Duke. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Gwe.
sp.p: I thang you good peggers, ha ha, this is fine sport, by God is have peggers eat her fittales all day long.

div.stage: Enter sir Owen and Rees.

sp.speaker: Ow.
sp.p: Where is the sheer Rees? Cod's plude where?

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: I beseech you sir be patient, I tell you the beggars have it.

sp.speaker: Owen.
sp.p:
Wad a pogs is do with peggers? wad is peggers
●●

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: How my lady Gwenthian? ha ha ha.

div.stage: Enter marquess, Julio, Onophria, Urcenze, Mario.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: You see sir Owen we are soon invited,
Where is your wife the lady Gwenthian?

sp.speaker: Owen.
sp.p: Is come pie and pie, cod udge me Gwenthian prey put on your bravery and fine knags, and shame not sir Owen, yes truly Gwenthian is come out pie and pie, man grass worth whee cozen marquess, man grass worth whee cozen Jolia is welcome awl.

sp.speaker: Fa
sp.p: Ha ha welcome, come come madam appear in your likeness, or rather in the likeness of another, my lord you're best send back to your own cooks, if you mean to set your teeth a work today.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.p: Why Farneze what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Nay there's no matter in it, the fire's quenched, the victuals given to beggars, sir Owen's kitchen looks like the first chaos, or like a broker's stall, full of odd ends: or like the end of some terrible battle, for upon every dresser lies legs and feathers, and heads of poor capons and wild foul that have been drawn and quartered, and now mourn that their carcases are carried away: his are not rheumatic, for there's no spitting here lie fish in a pitiful pickle, there stands the coffins of pies, wherein the dead bodies of birds should have been buried, but their ghosts have forsaken their graves and walked abroad: the best sport is to see the scullions, some laughing, some crying, and whilst they wipe their eyes they black their faces, the cooks curse her lady, and some pray for our lord.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.p: Sir Owen Meredith is all this true?

sp.speaker: Ow.
sp.p: True, et is true I warrant her pogs on her too true.

sp.speaker: Ono.
sp.p: You told his grace you had tamed your wife.

sp.speaker: Owen.
sp.p:
By cod is tell her a lie then, her wise has pridled
and tamed her indeed: cozen marquess pecause Grissel is made fool and turn away, Gwenthian mag fool of sir Owen: is good? ha, is good?

sp.speaker: Gwen.
sp.p: 'Tis lie cozen marquess, is terrible lie: rawsone en ennoh twewle, 'tis lie, 'tis lie, sit Owen tear her repatoes and ruffs, and pridle her latie, and bid her hang herself, but is pridled I warrant her, is not sir Owen?

sp.speaker: Owe.
sp.p: Adologg whee bethogh en thlonigh, en moyen due, Gwenthian.

sp.speaker: Gwe.
sp.p: Ne vetho en thlonigh, gna watha gethla tee.

sp.speaker: Vrc.
sp.p: What says she sir Owen?

sp.speaker: Owe.
sp.p: I pray and pray her for cod's love be quiet, 'sploud her say her will not be quiet, do what sir Owen can: mon due Gwenthian, me knock the pen, en umbleth, pobe des, and pobe nose.

sp.speaker: Gwe.
sp.p: Gwenogh olcha vessagh whee, en herawgh, ee.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p: Stand between them Farneze.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.p: You shall bob no nose here.

sp.speaker: Gwe.
sp.p: En herawgh ee? Me gravat the legatee, athlan ith' pendee ▪ adroh ornymee on dictar, en hecar ee.

sp.speaker: Ono.
sp.p: Doth she threaten you sir Owen? bind her to the peace.

sp.speaker: Owe.
sp.p: By cod is threaten her indeed, her says she'll scratch out sir Owen's eyes, and her frown upon her, a pogs on her nails.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: O my dear Grissel, how much different
Art thou to this cursed spirit here, I say
My Grissel's virtues shine sir Meredith.
And cousin Gwenthian come I'll have you friends,
This dinner shall be saved, and all shall say,
'Tis done, because 'tis Gwenthyan's fasting day.

sp.speaker: Gwe.
sp.p: Gwenthian scorns to be friends, her lady will be master sir Owen.

sp.speaker: Ow.
sp.p:
By cod I'll see her latie hanged first: cozen marquess and cozens awl, pray tag time and stay here, Rees shall
dress more fittels, and shall dine her in spite of her lady: cod 'sploud Rees Rees. Exit.

sp.speaker: Gwe.
sp.p: Will you? Is try that pie and pie: stethe whee lawer, cousin marquess stethe whee lawer shentlemen, Gwenthian is not pridled so soon. Exit.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.p: I'll see the peace kept sure, do what he can, I doubt his wife will prove the better man. Exit.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Signior Mario you say nothing, how like you this interlude?

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.p: So well madam, that I rather with to play the beggar, than a King's part in it in sir Owen's apparel.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Why this it is to be married, thus you see those that go to woo, go to woe, o for a drum to summon all my lovers, my suitors, my servants together.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: I appear sweet mistress without summons.

sp.speaker: Ono.
sp.p: So does Onophrio.

sp.speaker: Vrc.
sp.p: So does Urcenze.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Signior Emulo I see will not be seen without calling.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.p: No faith madam, he's blown up, no calling can serve him, he has ta'en another manner of calling upon him, and I hope repents the folly of his youth.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p: If he follow that vocation well, he'll prove wealthy in wit.

sp.speaker: Vrc.
sp.p: He had need for his head is very poor.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.p: Well mistress we appear without drumming, what's your parley (And yet not so) your eyes are the drums that summons us.

sp.speaker: Vrc.
sp.p: And your beauty the colours we fight under.

sp.speaker: Ono.
sp.p: And the touch of your soft hand, arms us at all points with devotion to serve you, desire to obey you, and vows to love you.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p: Nay then in faith make me all soldier, mine eyes a drum, my beauty your colours, and my hand your armour: what becomes of the rest?

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.p: It becomes us to rest, before we come to the rest, yet for a need we could turn you into an armoury: as for example, your lips (Let me see) no point of war for your lips? can I put them to no use but kissing? o yes, if you change them to shoot out unkind language to us that stand at your mercy, they are two culverins to destroy us.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: That I'll try: my tongue shall give fire to my words presently.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: O be more merciful fair Julia.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Not I, would you have me pity you and punish myself? would you wish me to love? when love is so full of hate? how unlovely is love? how bitter? how full of blemishes, my lord and brother insults our Grissel, that makes me glad, Gwenthyan curbs sir Owen, that makes you glad, sir Owen is mastered by his mistress that makes you mad, poor Grissel is martyred by her lord that makes you merry, for I always wish that a woman may never meet better bargains, when she'll thrust her sweet liberty into the hands of a man: fie upon you, you're nothing but wormwood, and oak, and glass: you have bitter tongues, hard hearts, and brittle faith.

sp.speaker: Ono.
sp.p: Condemn us not till you try our loves.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Sweet servant speak not in this language of love, Gwenthyan's peevishness and Grissel's patience, make me here to defy that ape Cupid, if you love stand upon his laws, I charge you leave it, I charge you neither to sigh for love nor speak of love, nor frown for hate: if you sigh I'll mock you, if you speak I'll stop mine ears, if you frown I'll bend my fist.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.p: Then you'll turn warrior in deed.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Had I not need encountering with such enemies? but say will you obey and follow me or disobey, and I'll fly you.

sp.speaker: Ono.
sp.p: I obey since it is your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Vrc.
sp.p: I obey though I taste no pleasure in it.

sp.speaker: Farn.
sp.p: I obey to, but so God help me mistress I shall show you a fair pair of heels and cry a new mistress a new, if any pitiful creature will have me.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Better lost than found if you be so wavering.

div.stage: Enter marquess Lepido, sir Owen, Gwenthyan brave, and Furio.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Furio hie thee to old Ianicola's,
Charge him, his daughter Grissel, and his son
To come to court, to do such office,
Of duty to our marriage, as shall like
Our state to lay upon them.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: O my lord,
Vex not poor Grissel more, alas her heart,

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Tut tut, I'll have my will and tame her pride,
I'll make her be a servant to my bride,
Julia I'll bridle her.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: You do her wrong.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Sister correct that error, come sir Owen,
Is not this better music than your brawls?

sp.speaker: Ow.
sp.p: Yes as cod udg me is: how cozen Julia, is out a cry friends now, Gwenthyan is laugh and be ferie patience now sir Owen kiss her lady, a great teale now: see else?

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.p: I but sir Owen, the kissing her lady is no mirth to us, if we kiss the post.

sp.speaker: Owe.
sp.p: Owe her cozen marquess has terrible mighty news for tell her, or else is made ready a great banquet at home for awl, pray come home, is all ready for her, her lady say not bopeep now: but first hear her cozen marquess news.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Julia and gentlemen these are the news,
Brought on the wings of haste and happiness,
By trusty Lepido our endeared brother,
Is hard at hand who in his company,
Brings my fair second choice a worthy bride,
attended by the states of Pavia,
She's daughter to the Duke of Brandenburg,
Now shall no subject's envious soul repine,
And call her base whom now I will make mine,
None shall upbraid me now, (As they have done)
That I will slay a daughter and a son,
Grissel's ▪ two babes are dead, and killed by scorn,
But that fair issue that shall now be born
Shall make a satisfaction of all wrongs.
Come gentlemen we will go meet this train,
Let every one put on a smiling brow,
Sir Owen I will have your company,
And yours fair cozen: well remembered to,
Bring your three wands sir Owen to the court,
Though Gwenthyan look with a smoother eye,
I'll teach you how to win the sovereignty.

sp.speaker: Ow.
sp.p: Is glad of that, ha, ha, ha, tag heed of wands
Lady,

sp.speaker: Gwen.
sp.p: Tag heed of nails knight,

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: We play the unthrifts in consuming time,
Though your cursed wife make some afraid to woe
Yet I'll woe once more and be married to.

sp.speaker: Ow.
sp.p: Cod udge me sir Owen would hang before her marry once more, if I were another patcheler: marry owe. Exeunt omnes.

div.stage: Enter Laureo reading and Babulo with him.

sp.speaker: Bab.
sp.p: Come I have left my work to see what matins you mumble to yourself, faith Laureo I would you could leave this Latin, and fall to make baskets, you think 'tis enough if at dinner you tell us a tale of pigmies, and then munch up our victuals, but that fits not us: or the history of the well Helicon, and then drink up our bear we cannot live upon it.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: A scholar doth disdain to spend his spirits, upon such base employments as hand labours.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: Good Furio vanish, we have no appetite, tell your master, clowns are not for the court, we'll keep court ourselves, for what do courtiers but we do the like: you eat good cheer, and we eat good bread and cheese: you drink wine, and we strong bear: at night you are as hungry slaves as you were at noon, why so are we: you go to bed, you can but sleep, why and so do we: in the morning you rise about eleven of the clock, why there we are your betters, for we are going before you: you wear silks, and we sheepskins, innocence caries it away in the world to come, and therefore vanish good Furio, torment us not good my sweet Furio.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Ass I'll have you snaffled,

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: It may be so, but then Furio I'll kick.

sp.speaker: Fu.
sp.p: Will you go, or shall I force you?

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: You need not, for I'll run to serve my lord,
Or if I wanted legs, upon my knees
I'll creep to court so I may see him pleased,
Then courage father.

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.l: Well said patience,
Thy virtue's arm mine age with confidence,
Come son, bondmen must serve, shall we away?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Ay, ay, but this shall prove a fatal day.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: Brother, for my sake do not wrong yourself.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Shall I in silence bury all our wrongs?

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: Yes when your words cannot get remedy,
Learn of me Laureo I that share most woe,
Am the least moved, father lean on mine arm,
Brother lead you the way, whilst wretched I
Uphold old age, and cast down misery.

sp.speaker: Fu.
sp.p: Away.

sp.speaker: Ba,
sp.p: Old m. you have fished fair and catched a frog.Exeunt
sp.stage: Enter marquess, Pavia Lepido, Onophrio, Urcenze, Farnezi, and Mario.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Lords as you love our state, affect our loves,
like of your own content, respect your lives,
Urge us no further, Gualther is resolved,
To marry the half heir of Brandenburg,
My brother Pavia with no small expense,
Hath brought the Princess out of Germany.
Together with prince Gualther her young brother,
Now they are come, learn of the rising sun,
Scatter the cloudy mists of discontent,
As he disperseth vapours with his beams.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.l: Brother, there is no eye but brightly shines,
Gladness doth lodge in your nobles looks,
Nor have they any cause to cloud their brows.

div.stage: Enter sir Owen, Gwenthian, and Rees with wandes:

sp.speaker: Far
sp.p: O here comes sir Owen, and my lady patience, come there.

sp.speaker: Owen.
sp.p: Tardaugh cousin marquess and lawrdes awl.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Welcome good cousin Gwenthian, will you please go in, and lend your presence to my bride?

sp.speaker: Gwe.
sp.p: Cousin, 'tis her intentions so to do, but I swear and I were Grissel ▪ I would pull her eyes out, and she were as many sharmaines daughter is there be cows in Cambria and that is above twenty score and a lidle more, you know sir Owen?

sp.speaker: Ow.
sp.p: Yes truly above a dozen more is warrant her.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.p: Grissel is patient madam, be you pleased.

sp.speaker: Gwen.
sp.p: Well, and she be so baselies minded 'tis well, but I know whad I know sir Owen here thinks to make Gwenthyan's so patience, sir Owen 'tis awl in veins, well I go to her brides. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ow.
sp.p: You prade and you taug Gwenthyan's, but I made you put on parrels for awl your taug and prade: Rees, where's Rees spring the wands here Rees.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: They are here sir, in the twinkling of an eye.

sp.speaker: Owe.
sp.p: Cousin, when her weddings are done and at leisures, I will learn your medicines to tame shrews.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.p: You shall anon good cousin Meredith.

sp.speaker: Ow.
sp.p: Stand by Rees, walk in the halls among the servingman's, keep her wands till I call, hear you now?

div.stage: Inter Furio.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Yes sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.p: Furio are Grissel and the other come?

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Yes, they are come.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.p: Are they employed according to our charge?

sp.speaker: Fu.
sp.p: They are.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.p: How does her brother take it?

sp.speaker: Fu.
sp.p: Iii.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.p: How her father?

sp.speaker: Fu.
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.p: How herself?

sp.speaker: Fu.
sp.p: Better.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.p: Furio, go call out Grissel from the bride.

sp.speaker: Fu.
sp.p: I will. Exit Furio.

sp.speaker: Farn.
sp.p: It's pity that fellow was not made a soldier, he should have but a word and a blow at his hands.
sp.stage: Enter lanicola and Babulo carrying coals, Laureo with wood, Grissill with wood.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: Master go you but under the cowl-staff, Babulo can bear all, staff basket and all.

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.l: It is the marquess pleasure I must drudge,
Load me I pray thee, I am born to bear.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: But I'll no longer bear a logger head,
Thus I'll cast down his fuel in despite,
So, though my heart be sad, my shoulder's light.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: Alas what do you brother, see you not
Our dread lord yonder ▪ come perform his will,
O in a subject this is too too ill.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: What meanest thou fellow to cast down thy load?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: I have cast down my burden not my load,
The load of your gross wrongs lies here like lead.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.p: What fellow is this?

sp.speaker: Gris.
sp.p: Your handmaid Grissel's brother,

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.p: Take him away into the posters lodge,

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Lodge me in dungeons, I will still exclaim,
On Gualther's cursed acts and hated name. Exit. with Marq.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.p: Grissel take you his load and bear it in.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: O tiger minded monstrous marquess, make thy lady a collier?

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.p: What's that that villain prates so?

sp.speaker: Bab.
sp.p: God bless the noble marquess,

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Sirrah take you his coals, Grissel depart,
Return but bear that first,

sp.speaker: Gris.
sp.p: With all my heart. Exeunt. Gris. and Ba. grinning at him.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.p: Stay you Janicola, I have heard you sing,

sp.speaker: Jan
sp.p: I could have sung when I was free from care.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.p: What grief can in your aged bosom lie?

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.p: Grief that I am ungracious in your eye,

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: Then would he not desire your company ▪

div.stage: Enter Grissill.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Janicola here is a bridal song,
Play you the lark to greet my blessed sun,
Grissel are you returned? play you the morning,
To lead forth Gratiana my bright bride
Go in and wait on her Janicola.
Sing Hymeneus hymns, music I say. Exit. Grissill.

sp.speaker: Ow.
sp.l: Tawsone tawsone cozens aul, and here harmonies and sol faes.

div.stage: The song.
div.l: Song. Beauty arise, show forth thy glorious shining,
Thine eyes feed love, for them he standeth pining,
Honour and youth attend to do their duty,
Beauty arise, whilst we thy servants sing,
Jove to Hymen wedlock jocund King.
Of wedlock, love, and youth is Hymen King.
Beauty arise, beauty arise, thy glorious lights display ▪
Whilst we sing so, glad to see this day,
Io io io Hymen io io sing,
Of wedlock, love, and youth is Hymen King.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Art thou as glad in soul as in thy song?

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.l: Who can be glad when he endureth wrong?

sp.speaker: Ow.
sp.p: As cod udge me Ian Niclas is honest man, he does not flatter and sembles, but tell his intentions: owe more melodies, owe here come her new pride.

div.stage: Music sounds, enter Grissill alone, after her the marquess son and daughter, Julia, Gwenthian and other ladies, and Mario and Furio.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Salute my beauteous love.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: All joy betide to Gratiana our dear marquess bride.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Bring me a crown of gold to crown my love,
A wreath of willow for despised Grissel.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: Grissel is not despised in your eye,
Sithence you name her name so gently.

sp.speaker: Ow.
sp.l: Gwenthyan's there's wiues, there's patient wives

sp.speaker: Gwe
sp.l: Fuh fuh is fools, tawsone is arrant pobie fools.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Grissel place you this crown upon her head,
Put these embroidered slippers on her feet.
'Tis well, deliver me your wedding ring,
Circle her finger with it, now stand by,
Art thou content with all?

sp.speaker: Gris.
sp.p: Content with all.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: My bride is crowned, now tell me all of you,
Which of you ever saw my love before?
What is her name, her birth, place, or estate,

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.p: Till now I never beheld her beauty.

sp.speaker: Ono.
sp.p: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Vrc.
sp.p: Trust me nor I.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: By my troth nor I.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: We hear that she was born in Germany,
And half heir to the Duke of Brandenburg.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.p: You all hear this, and all think this?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: We do.

sp.speaker: Marq
sp.l: Then fu. stand thou forth, lords in his breast
A loyal servants true soul doth rest,
Furio shall be apparelled in a robe.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: I shall not become it.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Some that are great put robes on parasites,
Mario, Lepido come you two hither,
Are not you richly clad? have I done so?

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: What means your grace by this?

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.p: Graceless, have done,
sp.l: Truth, seldom dwells in a still talking tongue,
Furio bring Laureo from the porter's lodge,
Take in Janicola, and cloth them both
In rich abiliments, they shall awhile
Be flattered with false fortunes wanton smiles.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Fortune can do no more than she hath done,
They that are marked to woe, to woe must run. Exit Futio and Janicola.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.p: How do you like my bride?

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: I think her blessed.
To have the love of such a noble lord.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.p: You flatter me.

sp.speaker: Grissi.
sp.l: Indeed I speak the truth,
Only I prostrately beseech your grace,
That you consider of her tender years,
Which as a flower in spring may soon be nipped,
With the least frost of cold adversity.

sp.speaker: Marq
sp.l: Why are not you then nipped? you still seem fresh
As if adversities cold icy hand,
Had never laid his fingers on your heart.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: It never touched my heart, adversity
Dwells still with them that dwells with misery,
But mild content hath eased me of that yoke,
Patience hath born the bruise and I the stroke.

div.stage: Enter Furio, Janicola, and Laureo, striving about attire.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Give him his silks they shall not touch my back

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: What strife is there, what aileth Laureo?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: I will not wear proud trappings like a beast,
Yet hourly feel the scornful rider's spur,

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Cloth old Janicola in rich attire,

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.l: Do, load me, for to bear is my desire.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Do ye repine, nay then I'll vex you more,
Grissel I will receive this second wife
From none but from thy hands: come give her me,

sp.speaker: Gris.
sp.l: I here present you with an endless bliss,
Rich honour, beauteous virtue, virtuous youth,
Long live my lord with her contentedly.

sp.speaker: Owe.
sp.p: Marg patience there Gwenthyan see you thade ▪

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Grissel dost thou deliver me this maid,
As an untainted flower which I shall keep,
Despite of envy's canker, till the rust,
Of all consuming death finish her life?

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: I do my dear lord, and as willingly
As I delivered up my maiden youth.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: What says Janicola?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I say but thus,
Great men are gods, and they have power o'er us,

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Grissel hold fast the right hand of my bride,
Thou wearest a willow wreath and she a crown,
True bride take thou the crown and she the wreath,

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: My gracious lord you do mistake yourself.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Peace peace, thou sycophant Grissel receive
Large interests for thy love and sufferance.
Thou gavest me this fair maid, I in exchange,
Return thee her: and this young gentleman
Thy son and daughter kiss with patience,
And breathe thy virtuous spirit into their souls.

sp.speaker: Gwe.
sp.p: Owe sir Owen marg you now, the man is yielded to her latie, learn now sir Owen learn, learn knight your duty, see you thade?

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Why stands my wronged Grissel thus amazed?

sp.speaker: Gris.
sp.l: Joy fear, love hate, hope doubts encompass me.
Are these my children I supposed slain?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Are these my nephews that were murdered?

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: Blessing distil on you like morning dew,
My soul knit to your souls, knows you are mine.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: They are, and I am thine: lords look not strange,
These two are they, at whose births envies tongue,
Darted envenomed stings, these are the fruit
Of this most virtuous tree, that multitude,
That many headed beasts, nipped their sweet hearts,
With wrongs, with bitter wrongs, all you have wronged her,
Myself have done most wrong, for I did try
To break the temper of true constancy:
But these whom all thought murdered are alive,
My Grissel lives, and in the book of fame,
All worlds in gold shall register her name.

sp.speaker: Le. Mar.
sp.l: Most dreaded lord.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Arise flatterers get you gone,Exeunt Lep. ma.
Your souls are made of black confusion.
Father Janicola.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: O pardon me,
Though dumb betwixt my grief and joy I be.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Who stands thus sad, what brother Laureo?

sp.speaker: Eau.
sp.l: Pardon me my gracious lord, for now I see,
That scholars with weak eyes, poor on their books,
But want true souls to judge on majesty:
None else but Kings can know the hearts of Kings,
Hence forth my pride shall fly with humbler wings.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Our pardon and our love circle thee round,
Let's all to banquet, mirth our cares confound.

sp.speaker: Ow.
sp.p: Hold, hold, hold, banquet? if you banquet so, sir Owen is like to have sheer, her latie here is cog a hoop now at this, pray cousin keep your promise, Rees the wands Rees, your medicines and fine trigs to tame shrews.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.p: Furio where be the wands that I bound up?

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Here my lord.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: I wreathed them then sir Owen, and you see
They still continue so, wreath you these three.

sp.speaker: Ow.
sp.p: Owe wind them, yes is winde them and mag good mighty cudgel, to tame and knog her latie, and she prawle, or cry, or give preade and meat to peggers, or tear ponds, by God is well remembered too, cousin you promised to help her to her duckegs, for all her paper and ponds is torn?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And I will keep my promise, wreath your wands

sp.speaker: Owen.
sp.p: Owe God's lid mine is stubborn like Gwenthyan's, God's plude see it preakes in snipsnap pieces, what now cousin?

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: But cozen these you see did gently bow,
I tried my Grissel's patience when 'twas green,
Like a young over, and I moulded it
Like wax to all impressions: married men
That long to tame their wives must curb them in,
Before they need a bridle, than they'll prove
All Grissel's full of patience, full of love,
Yet that old trial must be tempered so,
Lest seeking to tame them they master you.

sp.speaker: Owen.
sp.l: By God is true as pistol and gospel, o true out a cry.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: But you sir Owen giving her the head,
As you gave liberty to those three wands,
She'll break as those do if you bend her now,
And then you're passed all help, for if you strive,
You'll gain as gamesters do that seldom thrive.

sp.speaker: Owe.
sp.p: What shall do to her latie then? is pest run away cozen, or knog her brains out? for is as faliant as Mars if I be anger.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p:
That were a shame either to run away from a woman or to strike her, your best physic sir Owen, is to wear a velvet hand, leaden ears, and no tongue, you must not fight howsoever she quarrels, you must be deaf
whensoever she brawls, and dumb when yourself should brabble: take this caudle next your heart every morning, and if your wife be not patient, the next remedy that I know is, to buy your winding sheet.

sp.speaker: Gwe.
sp.p: Cousin marquess, cozen Julia, and lawrds and laties all, it shall not need as her cozen has tried Grissel, so Gwenthian has sir Owen,

sp.speaker: Ow.
sp.p: Owe, by cod is thought should pull her down, ah ha.

sp.speaker: Gwe.
sp.p: Is not pulled down neither, but sir Owen shall be her head, and is sorry has anger her head and mag it ache, but pray good knight be not proud and triumph too much and freade her latie down, God udge me will tag her will again do what her can.

sp.speaker: Ow.
sp.p: By cod is love her out a cry now, sir Owen could tame her before, but Prittish ploude scorns to side withlaties, yes faith scorns out a cry, a pogs on't 'tis naught: Gwenthian shall no more be called Gwenthian but patient Grissel, ah ha is.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.p: Our joys are complete, forward to our feast, patience hath won the prize and now is blessed.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p: Nay brother your pardon awhile: besides ourselves there are a number here, that have beheld Grissel's patience, you own trials, and sir Owen's sufferance, Gwenthyan's forwardness, these gentlemen lovertine and myself a hater of love: amongst this company I trust there are some maiden bachelors, and virgin maidens, those that live in that freedom and love it, those that know the war of marriage and hate it, set their hands to my bill, which is rather to die a maid and lead apes in hell, than to live a wife and be continually in hell.

sp.speaker: Gwen.
sp.p:
Julia by your leaves a lidle while, you taug and you prabble about shidings in marriages, and you abuse young men's and damsels, and frayed them from good sports and honourable states: but hear you now, awl that be sembled here, know you that discords mag good music,
and when loners fall out is soon fallen in, and 'tis good you knaw: pray you all be married, for wedlock increases peoples and cities, awl you then that have husbands that you would pridle, set your hands to Gwenthyan's pill, for 'tis not fid that poor women's should be kept always under.

sp.speaker: Marquess
sp.l: Since Julia of the maids, and Gwenthian
Of froward wives, entreat a kind applaud,
See Grissel among all this multitude,
Who will be friend to gentle patience?

sp.speaker: Ow.
sp.p: Ha ha ha, Grissel is weary, pray let sir Owen speag Grissel is patient, and her cozen is patient, therefore is speage for two, god's plude you see her latie is spride of buttery, yet sir Owen tame her and tear her ruffs, and mag her cry and put ou her parrels, and say is sorry sir Owen, marg that well: if sir Owen was not patient, her latie had not been pridled, if Grissel had not been patient her cozen marquess had not been pridled: well now if you love sir Owen's latie, I hope you love sir Owen too, or is grow mighty angry, sir Owen love you as God udge me out a cry, a terrible feal, do you hear now, then pray awl that have crabbed husbands and cannot mend them, as Grissel's had, and awl that have fixen wives, and yet is tame her well enough as sir Owen does, and awl that have scolds as sir Owen does, and awl that love fair laties as sir Owen does, to said her two hands to his pill, and by God shall have sir Owen's herd and soul in his pellie: and so God save you all. Man grass wortha whee, man grass wortha whee. God night cousin's awl. Exeunt.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
